Activities teach valuable life lessons and can help reinforce lessons learned in the classroom. Cutting students off from these learning opportunities may do more harm than good when it comes to their overall development and success in school. 

A B average is also an very high bar that will exclude dedicated and hard-working students who happen to struggle more in certain subjects due to learning differences or challenges outside of school. This “one size fits all” approach does not consider individual student circumstances and needs. A more balanced approach, such as requiring a C average but developing targeted academic support for those close to failing, would be fairer while still promoting academic achievement. 

In closing, while the intent of raising standards is understandable, an inflexible B average requirement will negatively impact many deserving students without necessarily improving motivation or performance. I urge you to reconsider and suggested a more moderate, customized approach that supports all students’ well-being and success. Thank you for your consideration.

Sincerely,
[Your name]

essay_title: In "The Challenge of Exploring Venus," the author suggests studying Venus is a worthy pursuit despite the dangers it presents. Using details from the article, write an essay evaluating how well the author supports this idea. Be sure to include: a claim that evaluates how well the author supports the idea that studying Venus is a worthy pursuit despite the dangers; an explanation of the evidence from the article that supports your claim; an introduction, a body, and a conclusion to your essay.
essay_text:
Studying Venus presents grave dangers due to its formidable atmosphere and surface conditions. However, in the article "The Challenge of Exploring Venus," the author makes a compelling case that such a risky endeavor would yield valuable scientific rewards, and is therefore a worthwhile pursuit despite the threats it poses. 

The author supports this idea with several key pieces of evidence. First, Venus shares many similarities with Earth as an terrestrial planet, yet evolved along a very different path due to a runaway greenhouse effect. Comparing the divergent planetary histories of Earth and Venus could provide crucial insight into Earth's climate and guide efforts to prevent human-caused global warming. Additionally, Venus's dense atmosphere may preserve geological records going back billions of years, granting clues about the early Solar System. Finally, Venus offers a unique environment to test engineering innovations like thermal and chemical protections to withstand extreme atmospheric extremes. 

In conclusion, while exploring Venus clearly comes with severe challenges and risks, the article effectively argues this difficulty is outweighed by the opportunity to gain profound scientific knowledge. Comparative planetary study of Venus and Earth could yield lessons vital for Earth's environmental management and sustainability. Venus also provides a testbed to build technologies applicable to exploring other planets and moons with harsh climates. Therefore, despite the inherent dangers, the potential scientific rewards outlined by the author make studying Venus a pursuit deserving of pursuing, as long as adequate precautions are taken to ensure crew and equipment safety. The article makes a persuasive case that expanding our understanding of Venus is a goal worthy of overcoming substantial obstacles.

essay_title: You have read the article 'Unmasking the Face on Mars.' Imagine you are a scientist at NASA discussing the Face with someone who thinks it was created by aliens. Using information in the article, write an argumentative essay to convince someone that the Face is just a natural landform.Be sure to include: claims to support your argument that the Face is a natural landform; evidence from the article to support your claims; an introduction, a body, and a conclusion to your argumentative essay.
essay_text:
While some claim that the Face on Mars is evidence of ancient alien life, the facts point to a natural explanation. The landmarks that make up the infamous "Face" are simply the result of natural geological patterns and processes. 

Many features of the "Face" can be explained by natural landform processes alone. The article discusses how tunnel-like features in the rock are actually just narrow ridges created through millions of years of erosion. Wind erosion in particular plays a major role in shaping the rock layers into inclined patterns. Moreover, darkness under overhanging cliffs creates shadows that make some spots seem lighter or darker, mimicking facial features. 

Scientists have also studied rock layers in the area and determined their composition does not indicate any artificial cause. Instead, the layers show typical signs of deposition by wind or water erosion alone. The article notes extensive air photographs reveal the surrounding area shows the same rock formations, further proving this style of erosion pattern is widespread in the natural Martian landscape. 

Some have claimed redistribution of rocks by ancient intelligence better explains the symmetry of the "Face." However, the Viking photos actually show asymmetry in the formations and imperfections that disprove any precise artificial design. Over millions of years of geological change, any initial natural patterns would shift slightly through the forces of erosion, cracking, and layer movement. The "Face's" flaws are exactly what we would expect from an old natural structure, not an artificial one.

While speculation about life on Mars stirs the imagination, reasoning and evidence points to a more down-to-earth solution in this case. The "Face on Mars" is formed from the slow, mundane work of natural weathering and erosion alone. No ancient aliens were needed to shape this landscape feature. Its puzzles have been solved through scientific method and understanding of planetary geology, not extraordinary claims. When considering the facts, it becomes clear the "Face on Mars" is simply a natural rock formation, not a sign of off-world intelligence.

essay_title:
Your principal is considering changing school policy so that students may not participate in sports or other activities unless they have at least a grade B average. Many students have a grade C average.
She would like to hear the students' views on this possible policy change. Write a letter to your principal arguing for or against requiring at least a grade B average to participate in sports or other activities. Be sure to support your arguments with specific reasons.
essay_text:
Dear Principal, 

I am writing to respectfully argue against requiring students to have at least a B average in order to participate in sports and extracurricular activities. While good grades are important, imposing this grade restriction could negatively impact students in several ways.

First, disallowing participation for those with a C average may discourage students who are trying their best. For some students, sports or clubs are a motivating factor that encourages them to work hard in their classes too. Taking this away could lower morale and reduce academic motivation for borderline students who just miss the B cutoff. It is unfair to punish students who are making an effort but fall slightly below the grade threshold. 

Second, extracurricular activities teach valuable life lessons and skills that cannot be learned inside the classroom. Sports require teamwork, discipline, time management and working towards a common goal. Clubs often nurture creativity, leadership and responsibility. For students who struggle academically, or may have learning disabilities, these supplemental activities can help build confidence and support their development in other important ways. Restricting participation denies students access to these benefits.

Finally, raising the grade requirement could negatively impact diversity in our extracurricular programs. Students from low-income families or those facing challenges at home often find academic success more difficult through no real fault of their own. Excluding C average students could make sports and clubs less accessible, especially to those who may benefit the most. This works against our goal of inclusiveness at our school. 

While excellent grades should always be encouraged, participation in supplemental activities also plays an important role in student growth. A C average shows students are passing their classes and making an effort. I believe the benefits of allowing inclusion outweigh the costs of exclusion in this case. A grade restriction risks doing more harm than good. For these reasons, I respectfully ask that you reconsider imposing this policy change.

Thank you for your consideration. Please let me know if any part of my perspective would be helpful to discuss further.

Sincerely,
[Your name]

essay_title: Write a letter to your state senator in which you argue in favor of keeping the Electoral College or changing to election by popular vote for the president of the United States. Use the information from the texts in your essay. Manage your time carefully so that you can read the passages; plan your response; write your response; and revise and edit your response. Be sure to include a claim; address counterclaims; use evidence from multiple sources; and avoid overly relying on one source. Your response should be in the form of a multiparagraph essay. Write your response in the space provided.
essay_text:
Dear Senator, 

I am writing to express my strong support for changing our presidential election system to one decided by popular vote rather than the Electoral College. While the Electoral College system was established by the founders with the aim of creating a localized, representative election, evidence shows that it no longer serves this purpose and often produces results at odds with the will of the people.

One of the main counterarguments to abandoning the Electoral College is that it encourages candidates to build broader coalitions and avoid focusing only on a few highly populated areas. However, data shows that presidential campaigns are already overwhelmingly focused on a handful of swing states under the current system. According to national popular vote tracker websites, over 90% of campaign events and nearly all campaign ad spending in the 2020 election were concentrated in just six states. Such narrow targeting undermines the goal of encouraging geographically diverse support. 

It is also argued that without the Electoral College, small states would lose their influence. But according to United States Census data, 81% of Americans live in urban areas that are concentrated in just 16 states. Thus, the current system arguably favors rural voters over the urban majority. A national popular vote would give every American citizen an equal vote regardless of geographic location. It would better reflect the will of all Americans rather than depending on the outcome in a few swing states.

Most importantly, there have now been two presidential elections this century where the winner of the national popular vote did not win the Electoral College. This defies the fundamental principle of one person, one vote. As long as it remains possible for a candidate to lose the national vote but win in the arbitrary state-by-state Electoral College process, faith in our democratic system will continue to erode. For these reasons, I strongly believe we should transition to a national popular vote for electing the president.

Thank you for your consideration of this important issue. Please let me know if you have any other questions.

Sincerely,
[Your name]

essay_title: You have just read the article, 'A Cowboy Who Rode the Waves.' Luke's participation in the Seagoing Cowboys program allowed him to experience adventures and visit many unique places. Using information from the article, write an argument from Luke's point of view convincing others to participate in the Seagoing Cowboys program. Be sure to include: reasons to join the program; details from the article to support Luke's claims; an introduction, a body, and a conclusion to your essay.
essay_text:
Setting off into the unknown requires courage, but with courage comes reward. Each new horizon revealed sights more stunning than the last, from towering sandstone cliffs to seas so blue they didn't seem real. More than simple tourism, I gained true understanding of other ways of life by living among communities in places like the Caribbean and Mediterranean. True connection only happens face to face, not through books or movies. Bonding with crew from all over the world gave me friendships I hope will last a lifetime.

Adventure calls those willing to answer by stepping off the well-worn path. In the Seagoing Cowboys program, I pushed past my comfort zone to achieve things I never dreamed possible. I now know that questioning what lies beyond what's familiar opens doors to personal growth and lasting memories. Waves will always lap at coasts, and tall ships cut across oceans, so opportunities for discovering yourself and our shared planet will keep arising. I hope others will bravely grasp them as I did, and experience with their own eyes the life-changing adventures that awaited me offshore. Our world holds wonders waiting to be revealed to those bold enough to set sail on paths less traveled.

essay_title:
Some of your friends perform community service. For example, some tutor elementary school children and others clean up litter. They think helping the community is very important. But other friends of yours think community service takes too much time away from what they need or want to do.
- Your principal is deciding whether to require all students to perform community service.
- Write a letter to your principal in which you take a position on whether students should be required to perform community service. Support your position with examples.
essay_text:
Dear Principal, 

I am writing to you regarding the idea of requiring all students to perform community service. While helping others is certainly important, I do not think making it mandatory is the best approach. There are a few reasons for my position.

First, requiring community service risks making it feel like a chore rather than something students genuinely want to do to help their community. If the goal is to encourage students to become active and caring members of society, it is better for this to come from personal choice and motivation rather than obligation. Students who choose to volunteer are more likely to find it a rewarding experience that fosters positive values. 

Second, mandatory service takes away students' freedom to spend their free time as they wish. Especially for students who juggle many commitments like sports, jobs, and family responsibilities, their free hours are valuable. Forcing them to sacrifice that time may cause resentment rather than teach appreciation. It is better if students volunteer only when they feel they have capacity to take something meaningful from the experience.

Finally, there are certainly other ways for students to demonstrate good citizenship without dedication a set number of hours to service. Students who show kindness to others, participate thoughtfully in class, and exhibit strong character should not be penalized if they do not have the availability for organized volunteer activities. Civic participation comes in many forms.

In conclusion, while community service is extremely beneficial, making it compulsory risks diminishing its purpose and value. I believe students will support their communities most effectively if they choose to volunteer through their own motivation rather than obligation. Allowing voluntary participation respects students' agency and privacy while still encouraging civic involvement. For these reasons, I do not think it should be mandatory for all students.

Thank you for considering my perspective. Please let me know if you have any other questions.

Sincerely,
[Your name]

essay_title:
Your principal is considering changing school policy so that students may not participate in sports or other activities unless they have at least a grade B average. Many students have a grade C average.
She would like to hear the students' views on this possible policy change. Write a letter to your principal arguing for or against requiring at least a grade B average to participate in sports or other activities. Be sure to support your arguments with specific reasons.
essay_text:
Dear Principal Johnson, 

I am writing to express my views on the proposed policy change that would require students to maintain a B average in order to participate in sports and other extracurricular activities. While I understand the goal of wanting students to focus on their academics, I do not think requiring a B average is the best approach.

Requiring such a high GPA could discourage participation in extracurriculars for many students. For some students, activities like sports provide an important outlet and sense of belonging at school. Being part of a team helps build character, leadership skills, and time management. If they cannot participate due to one C grade bringing down their average, it may negatively impact their self-esteem and motivation. 

A C average still shows that students are passing their classes and making an effort. Small drops in a grade do not always indicate a lack of effort or priorities. Students have busy schedules with school, activities, jobs, and family responsibilities. One assignment or test could pull someone's average below a B through no major fault of their own. 

Extracurriculars can actually help academic performance for many students. Being engaged in school through activities provides balance that enhances learning. It also gives students a break from academics to recharge. Barring participation could remove these benefits for some. 

Rather than an outright ban for anyone below a B average, I think alternative arrangements like requiring study hall hours or monthly check-ins with teachers would better support student success. Extra support and accountability could help struggling students improve their grades to a level that allows continued participation. An all-or-nothing policy risks doing more harm than good.

In closing, while high academic standards are important, requiring a B average seems too restrictive and could deter involvement for many capable students. A more balanced approach would be in the best interest of the whole student body. I hope you will reconsider this proposed policy change.

Thank you for your consideration.

Sincerely,
[Your name]

essay_title: Your principal has decided that all students must participate in at least one extracurricular activity. For example, students could participate in sports, work on the yearbook, or serve on the student council. Do you agree or disagree with this decision? Use specific details and examples to convince others to support your position.
essay_text:
I disagree with the principal's decision to require all students to participate in at least one extracurricular activity. While extracurricular activities provide many benefits, forcing participation takes away students' freedom to choose how to spend their time. 

Not all students have the time or interest to commit to an extracurricular. Some students need time for other responsibilities like jobs, family duties, or religious commitments. Requiring extra activities leaves no flexibility for balancing these other priorities. It could add undue stress and take away from academics if a student is required to participate in an activity they do not genuinely enjoy.

Extracurricular activities are best if students freely choose ones that match their interests and strengths. Forcing participation means some students may be involved in activities they do not truly care about. This lessens the benefits of extracurriculars since engaged, interested participation is important for learning and personal growth. Students are more likely to build skills like time management, leadership, and teamwork if they are intrinsically motivated in an activity rather than participating just to fulfill a requirement. 

Instead of requiring participation, the principal could encourage students to get involved through appealing options and demonstrating how activities can complement academics. Recognizing that students have differing lives outside of school is important too. Not all students need an extracurricular to have a well-rounded education or helpful high school experience. Overall, while extracurricular activities offer advantages, participation should be a choice left to individual students and their specific needs or interests.

essay_title: In the article “Driverless Cars are Coming,” the author presents both positive and negative aspects of driverless cars. Using details from the article, create an argument for or against the development of these cars. Be sure to include: your position on driverless cars; appropriate details from the article that support your position; an introduction, a body, and a conclusion to your argumentative essay.
essay_text:
The Development of Driverless Cars 

In modern society, technology is rapidly advancing in almost every field. One area that is seeing major developments is transportation, specifically in the form of driverless or autonomous vehicles. However, the rise of this new technology presents both benefits and risks that must be carefully considered. After analyzing the positive and negative aspects of driverless cars as presented in the article "Driverless Cars are Coming," I am cautiously optimistic about their continued development.

One clear advantage discussed is improved safety. The article notes that around 90% of accidents are caused by human error in judgment or ability. By removing the human element from driving, many collisions could potentially be avoided through a vehicle's sensors and computer programming. Fewer accidents would mean less traffic fatalities and injuries. Driverless cars could also help the elderly and disabled maintain their mobility independently. Still, ensuring these cars can handle all road conditions safely is paramount before widespread adoption.

While driverless technology promises safety gains, concerns about privacy, cybersecurity and job disruption were also raised. Pushing personal location data to manufacturers raises privacy questions that require strong safeguards. Computer systems are vulnerable to hackers, so measures must be taken to prevent vehicles from being hijacked or crashes intentionally caused. Many driving jobs like taxis and delivery trucks could disappear, though new employment opportunities may emerge to support this new industry. Overall economic impacts are difficult to predict. 

In conclusion, the development of autonomous vehicles does present opportunities to save lives through accident prevention. However, significant challenges around privacy, security, and societal adjustments still exist and must not be ignored. With careful research and regulations to address these risks, driverless cars could transform transportation for the benefit of humans. But rushing unchecked into a fully autonomous future could also undermine safety if technologies are implemented prematurely. A balanced approach that monitors both promise and peril is necessary to maximize driverless cars' benefits while minimizing harms.

essay_title:
Your principal is considering changing school policy so that students may not participate in sports or other activities unless they have at least a grade B average. Many students have a grade C average.
She would like to hear the students' views on this possible policy change. Write a letter to your principal arguing for or against requiring at least a grade B average to participate in sports or other activities. Be sure to support your arguments with specific reasons.
essay_text:
Dear Principal, 

I am writing to express my views on the proposed policy change that would require students to have at least a B average in order to participate in sports and extracurricular activities. While maintaining good grades is important, I do not think imposing this grade restriction is the best approach.

Requiring a B average may discourage some students from participating in important activities that help them maintain overall wellness and balance. Sports and clubs can be impactful outlets that relieve stress from academic pressures. They also foster skills like teamwork, leadership, and time management – assets that are valuable both in and out of the classroom. For students who struggle more with certain subjects, extracurriculars may be what keeps them motivated and engaged in school. Taking that away could ultimately hurt their academic progress. 

A grade average alone does not define a student's willingness or work ethic. A C average does not mean someone is not trying their best, and growing as a student does not happen overnight. Some students may give greater effort on the playing field or in a club than they do in the classroom for various valid reasons. Excluding them could damage self-esteem and discourage further development. 

Instead of denying participation, I suggest offering academic support for students who want to improve. Tutoring, study halls, and check-ins with teachers could help those with lower averages boosttheir grades over time while still allowing involvement in activities important to their wellbeing. Extracurriculars complement learning when managed alongside – not in place of – academics. 

In closing, while maintaining standards is important, this policy change could undermine the benefits of activities and discourage students' growth. I ask that you reconsider and instead support alternatives that promote balance, persistence and achievement for all. The well-rounded development of every student should be the priority.

Thank you for considering my perspective. I welcome further discussion on this issue.

Sincerely,
[Your name]

essay_title:
Your principal is reconsidering the school's cell phone policy. She is considering two possible policies:
- Policy 1: Allow students to bring phones to school and use them during lunch periods and other free times, as long as the phones are turned off during class time.
- Policy 2: Do not allow students to have phones at school at all.
Write a letter to your principal convincing her which policy you believe is better. Support your position with specific reasons.
essay_text:
Dear Principal Smith, 

I am writing to you regarding the school's cell phone policy that is currently under reconsideration. Of the two policies being considered, I believe that Policy 1 is the better option that should be adopted. There are several reasons why allowing phones during lunch and free periods, but not during class time, is the preferable approach.

Firstly, many students rely on their cell phones to stay in touch with parents and guardians about after-school activities and transportation. If phones were banned entirely under Policy 2, it would make coordinating these important communications much more difficult both for students and their families. Policy 1 still allows this coordination to occur during non-academic times. 

Secondly, an outright ban on phones may lead to an increase in discipline issues if students try to sneak phones onto campus anyway. Policy 1 sets a clear rule about when phones can and cannot be used, making enforcement easier for teachers. Students will be less likely to break the rules if they are allowed some access. 

Finally, many students use their phones responsibly during lunch and breaks to call friends, play music, or check social media as a way to relax during their downtime. An all-out ban seems like an overreach and may upset students. Policy 1 strikes a fair balance that still allows personal device use during non-academic hours.

In conclusion, I believe Policy 1 is the better cell phone policy for our school. It maintains academic focus during class time but still provides students access to important communications tools and allows personal device use during free periods. This balanced approach will make both students and families happy. Please consider adopting Policy 1 for the upcoming semester.

Thank you for your consideration.

Sincerely,
[YOUR NAME]

essay_title: Write an explanatory essay to inform fellow citizens about the advantages of limiting car usage. Your essay must be based on ideas and information that can be found in the passage set. Manage your time carefully so that you can read the passages; plan your response; write your response; and revise and edit your response. Be sure to use evidence from multiple sources; and avoid overly relying on one source. Your response should be in the form of a multiparagraph essay. Write your essay in the space provided.
essay_text:
Limiting car usage has numerous benefits for citizens and the environment. According to sources 1 and 2, reducing individual car trips can improve public health and lower emissions of pollutants. Source 1 found that countries with higher rates of walking and cycling tend to have lower obesity levels. This suggests that incorporating more active transportation like biking or walking into daily commutes can help combat growing health issues. Source 2 noted the transportation sector is a leading contributor of greenhouse gas emissions and local air pollutants. Reducing car trips would therefore help improve air quality and mitigate the impacts of climate change. 

Aside from health and environmental advantages, limiting car usage can also offer economic benefits. As explained in source 3, the costs of personal vehicle ownership including gas, insurance, and maintenance are substantial expenses for most households. By relying less on cars for short trips and opting for public transportation, biking, or walking instead, people can save money that would otherwise go towards owning and operating a private vehicle. The passage also indicates these out-of-pocket savings could increase citizen disposable income and stimulate local economies. 

Finally, constraining road congestion through limiting car usage would bring about mobility benefits, according to source 4. By reducing the overall number of vehicles on roads during rush hours, public transit, biking, and walking become more viable options for transportation. With fewer cars clogging streets and highways, travel times would decline for all modes of transportation. Congestion costs like lost productivity from traffic delays could also be diminished. 

In summary, limiting car usage at both societal and individual levels offers a myriad of benefits across public health, the environment, personal finances, and transportation systems. citizens and communities as a whole would reap rewards by embracing modes of transportation that rely less on private vehicle ownership and usage. A shift towards more sustainable transportation choices could vastly improve quality of life.

essay_title: In "The Challenge of Exploring Venus," the author suggests studying Venus is a worthy pursuit despite the dangers it presents. Using details from the article, write an essay evaluating how well the author supports this idea. Be sure to include: a claim that evaluates how well the author supports the idea that studying Venus is a worthy pursuit despite the dangers; an explanation of the evidence from the article that supports your claim; an introduction, a body, and a conclusion to your essay.
essay_text:
Studying Venus Remains Worth the Risk

The article "The Challenge of Exploring Venus" makes a compelling case that studying Venus is a worthwhile objective in spite of the significant risks involved. The author outlines the perilous conditions on Venus but argues probing this planet's secrets could expand our understanding of Earth and the formation of habitable worlds. While Venus presents clear dangers, the potential scientific rewards outweigh these hazards according to the evidence presented.

A key piece of evidence that supports continuing Venus exploration is the opportunity to gain insights about terrestrial planet evolution. Venus may hold clues to why Earth developed an environment conducive to life while Venus did not. Comparing these neighboring planets could illuminate how factors like greenhouse gases, tectonic activity, and atmospheric chemistry interact to make a world livable. Advancing such knowledge has profound implications for NASA's search for life elsewhere and efforts to protect Earth's climate. 

Additionally, directly sampling Venus' atmosphere and surface would fill major scientific gaps. Current data comes solely from orbital observations, leaving many open questions. In situ exploration allows more detailed analysis and collecting physical samples for research back on Earth. The article notes several high priority measurements, like determining the planet's interior structure and precise composition, that require probes or landers. Resolving these uncertainties holds significance for planetary science on both Venus and Earth-sized worlds generally.

While Venus' hostile conditions like extreme heat and acid clouds introduce risk, the author makes a solid case this risk can be prudent. With carefully designed, durable vehicles and shorter mission durations, probes' chances of surviving long enough to beam back discoveries are reasonable according to NASA estimates. The potential gains in understanding planetary processes, habitability, and our own planet's evolution justify continued cautious investigation of Venus. Overall, the author effectively supports that Venus science remains a worthy pursuit in light of its hazards through compelling evidence about scientific promise and manageable mission risk.

essay_title:
Your principal is considering changing school policy so that students may not participate in sports or other activities unless they have at least a grade B average. Many students have a grade C average.
She would like to hear the students' views on this possible policy change. Write a letter to your principal arguing for or against requiring at least a grade B average to participate in sports or other activities. Be sure to support your arguments with specific reasons.
essay_text:
Dear Principal Smith,

I am writing to express my thoughts on the proposed policy change that would require students to have at least a B average in order to participate in sports and extracurricular activities. While maintaining good grades is important, instituting such a strict requirement may do more harm than good for many students. 

An exclusively grade-based eligibility policy fails to consider the diverse ways that students succeed. Some students truly excel in sports or clubs but struggle more in the classroom. limiting their involvement could negatively impact their emotional well-being, motivation, and sense of belonging at our school. Excluding students who work diligently but earn average Cs ignores the learning and development that comes from non-academic pursuits. 

A B average mandate may also have unintended academic consequences. The pressure of such high-stakes grades could increase stress levels for some and prove counterproductive to learning. Students running the risk of losing activities may focus on grade requirements over comprehension. Those on the cusp of a B could lessen extra effort or give up entirely. 

Rather than an across-the-board change, a more balanced approach is needed. Maintaining minimum GPA standards is reasonable but setting the bar at B excludes many capable students. Eligibility could depend on individual progress or teachers’ feedback on effort instead of just final marks. Tutoring programs could help those striving for improvement. Most importantly, we must recognize the multifaceted ways all students can succeed and encourage their growth in both academics and leadership through experience.

In closing, while upholding academic performance is essential, banning participation for average work risks compromising student wellness and missing larger goals of development. A more nuanced policy considering each student’s full potential seems most aligned with our school’s educational mission. I hope these perspectives will be helpful as you consider options to balance challenge and support for our whole community.

Sincerely,
[Your name]

essay_title: Your principal has decided that all students must participate in at least one extracurricular activity. For example, students could participate in sports, work on the yearbook, or serve on the student council. Do you agree or disagree with this decision? Use specific details and examples to convince others to support your position.
essay_text:
I disagree with the principal's decision to make extracurricular activities mandatory for all students. While extracurriculars can be beneficial for some, forcing participation removes student choice and individual interests. Not all students have the time or desire to take on extra commitments outside of their academics. 

Requiring extracurricular activities limits students' freedom to decide how to spend their free time. Some prefer focusing solely on schoolwork and grades to prepare for college or a career. Others may need to work part-time jobs or care for family members after school. Obligating extracurriculars ignores these students' circumstances and priorities. Rather than mandating participation, the school should emphasize the optional nature of extracurriculars and encourage students to choose activities aligned with their strengths, schedules and future goals.

Moreover, making extracurriculars compulsory could damage the quality of certain programs. Students who join only because they have to may lack genuine passion or commitment. As a result, sports teams may not practice or compete as effectively if roster spots are filled by uninterested athletes. Clubs and organizations may struggle if members attend meetings half-heartedly without real investment in the cause or activities. Forced involvement could diminish motivation, morale and enjoyment for other voluntary participants as well.  

To better support students' well-being and success, the principal should reconsider the mandatory extracurricular policy. Encouragement and promotion of opportunities are preferable to imposition. Students will achieve more and feel empowered if allowed freedom in deciding how to balance academics, activities and personal lives during their high school years. Overall well-rounded development happens most organically through voluntary participation in enriching pursuits that match individual talents, interests and schedules.

essay_title: In the article “Driverless Cars are Coming,” the author presents both positive and negative aspects of driverless cars. Using details from the article, create an argument for or against the development of these cars. Be sure to include: your position on driverless cars; appropriate details from the article that support your position; an introduction, a body, and a conclusion to your argumentative essay.
essay_text:
While driverless cars present opportunities, there are challenges worth addressing 

The development of driverless cars brings both promise and problems. On one hand, they could reduce accidents and free up time previously spent driving. Without human error, certain safety features may prevent collisions. And for those unable to drive, autonomous vehicles may provide valuable independence. At the same time, technological glitches could inadvertently cause harm. Public distrust may also arise. 

Rather than dismissing the idea outright, a balanced approach is needed. With further refinement, safety protocols could account for unexpected situations like construction zones. Lawmakers should establish guidelines to ensure accountability in case of malfunctions. Public education on automated vehicles' benefits could boost acceptance. For those still uncomfortable, conventional cars will likely remain an option.

Overall, the societal impacts of this technology deserve close consideration. If implemented prudently after addressing privacy, liability and technical issues, driverless cars may one day improve transportation. But rushing development risks undermining trust in autonomous vehicles before they realize their full potential. Careful testing and safeguards to address concerns will be key to gaining public support. With an open yet prudent mindset, many anticipated downsides could potentially be mitigated or avoided.  

In conclusion, while promising in many ways, driverless cars also present complex challenges. By acknowledging both opportunities and risks, and prioritizing safety through gradual change and oversight, this technology's development may one day enhance mobility for many in a responsible manner. But a measured, multipronged approach is prudent to ensure such impacts are realized.

essay_title: In "The Challenge of Exploring Venus," the author suggests studying Venus is a worthy pursuit despite the dangers it presents. Using details from the article, write an essay evaluating how well the author supports this idea. Be sure to include: a claim that evaluates how well the author supports the idea that studying Venus is a worthy pursuit despite the dangers; an explanation of the evidence from the article that supports your claim; an introduction, a body, and a conclusion to your essay.
essay_text:
The author makes a compelling case that studying Venus is worthy of our effort and resources despite the significant dangers it presents. While Venus has extreme conditions that are potentially lethal to humans and equipment, the author outlines several persuasive reasons why advancing our understanding of Venus through exploration and observation is still worthwhile. 

To begin with, the article notes Venus' similarities to Earth in terms of size and composition. As our neighboring planet, Venus provides an opportunity to gain insights into how conditions on Earth developed and our own planet's early history and evolution. Studying Venus can therefore help us understand fundamental questions about Earth itself. 

Furthermore, the author emphasizes Venus' unique features such as its dense atmosphere and greenhouse effect, details about which we could learn much more through additional probes. Because Venus shows us an example of runaway greenhouse warming, investigating Venus could ultimately yield insights applicable to climate change research here on Earth. Advancing our knowledge in this area has clear long-term benefits. 

Finally, the article outlines technological developments that have made exploring Venus' harsh environment more feasible in recent decades through improved probes and instrumentation. This demonstrates exploring Venus is an achievable goal if proper precautions are taken. The author also acknowledges exploring Venus presents "manageable" rather than impossible challenges. 

In summarizing these various lines of reasoning, the article makes a strong case that gaining knowledge of our closest planetary neighbor Venus through dedicated observation and exploration is immensely valuable scientifically, as the potential insights into pivotal questions like Earth's history and climate change merit enduring its hazards. While Venus poses serious risks, the author convincingly argues these dangers are outweighed by studying Venus' informativeness to significant scientific issues, thus rendering such endeavors well worth undertaking. In this way, the author effectively supports that exploring Venus remains a worthy scientific pursuit in spite of its dangers.

essay_title:
Your principal is reconsidering the school's cell phone policy. She is considering two possible policies:
- Policy 1: Allow students to bring phones to school and use them during lunch periods and other free times, as long as the phones are turned off during class time.
- Policy 2: Do not allow students to have phones at school at all.
Write a letter to your principal convincing her which policy you believe is better. Support your position with specific reasons.
essay_text:
Dear Principal Smith, 

I am writing to you regarding the school's cell phone policy options that are being reconsidered. Of the two proposals, I believe that Policy 1, which allows students to bring phones to school but requires them to be turned off during class time, is the better choice for our school. Here are a few reasons why:

Firstly, allowing phones during lunch and free periods recognizes that cell phones are an integral part of students' modern lives. For many students, their phones are how they communicate with friends and family outside of school hours. Banning phones entirely could negatively impact students' social lives and responsibilities. Policy 1 is a reasonable compromise that still allows students to be connected if needed during breaks. 

Secondly, keeping phones turned off during class time helps students focus on their studies without distractions. Research shows that constant phone notifications can hamper attention and increase temptation to check messages or apps during lessons. Policy 1 sets a clear rule about phone use to support effective learning. However, it still permits students to use devices responsibly when not engaged in teaching. An outright ban may be harder to enforce and build resentment.  

Finally, Policy 1 prepares students for the reality of phone usage in further education and careers. Universities and workplaces also require focusing on tasks at designated times but allow flexibility elsewhere. By introducing this balanced approach now, our students will develop important self-discipline skills for their futures. Policy 2 risks creating unrealistic expectations about Managing technology.

In conclusion, I believe Policy 1 is the best choice as it reasonably supports students' needs while prioritizing learning in class. Thank you for considering my perspective on this important issue. Please let me know if you need any other insights from students.

Yours sincerely,
[Your name]

essay_title:
Your principal is considering changing school policy so that students may not participate in sports or other activities unless they have at least a grade B average. Many students have a grade C average.
She would like to hear the students' views on this possible policy change. Write a letter to your principal arguing for or against requiring at least a grade B average to participate in sports or other activities. Be sure to support your arguments with specific reasons.
essay_text:
Dear Principal Smith, 

I am writing to express my concerns about the proposed policy change that would require students to maintain at least a B average in order to participate in sports and other extracurricular activities. While maintaining good grades is important, I do not think tying academic performance directly to participation is the best approach. 

There are a few reasons why requiring a B average may not be beneficial. For some students, sports and clubs are important for building skills like teamwork, time management, and leadership that cannot be learned inside the classroom. By taking part in activities, these students are able to develop important abilities that will help them both in and after school. Requiring a high GPA could prevent students who most need extracurricular opportunities from participating. 

Activities can also be a useful way for students struggling academically to relieve stress and stay motivated. Taking part in a sport or club gives students a positive outlet and reason to work hard at their other classes. Removing this outlet could actually cause grades to suffer for some. With less to break up their studies, struggling students may feel overwhelmed without a break. 

Finally, maintaining good grades is difficult for many students already managing packed schedules. Some students work part-time jobs or have family responsibilities outside of school. A B average may simply not be attainable no matter how hard these students work. Excluding them from all activities is an overly harsh consequence that does not consider outside factors impacting their performance.

A better approach, in my view, would be to require students below a C average to keep their grades from slipping further or develop a study plan. As long as they are showing academic progress even with a C average, they should have the option to participate. This policy encourages improvement without being overly punitive.

In closing, while maintaining acceptable grades is important, tying extracurricular participation to a high B average may do more harm than good for many dedicated students. I urge you to reconsider this proposed change and instead adopt a policy that motivates academic growth for all. Please let me know if you would like me to elaborate on any of my reasons.

Thank you for your consideration.

essay_title: You have just read the article, 'A Cowboy Who Rode the Waves.' Luke's participation in the Seagoing Cowboys program allowed him to experience adventures and visit many unique places. Using information from the article, write an argument from Luke's point of view convincing others to participate in the Seagoing Cowboys program. Be sure to include: reasons to join the program; details from the article to support Luke's claims; an introduction, a body, and a conclusion to your essay.
essay_text:
Traveling to Hawaii, Australia, and New Zealand opened my eyes to different environments and styles of managing cattle, but also reinforced that ranchers everywhere have much in common. In Hawaii, I helped repair fences on a ranch high up on volcanic slopes, tougher conditions than I'd ever seen back home! But the camaraderie between the cowboys there and their strong work ethic felt familiar. In Australia, I gained immense respect for stations that operate on vast tracts of remote rangeland. Adapting cattle breeds and techniques to arid climates showed the resilience of ranchers worldwide. 

Most memorable were my conversations with Māori ranchers in New Zealand. Hearing how their cultural traditions blend with ranching tradtions was truly fascinating. We discovered shared values of hard work, respect for the land and animals. Meeting people proud of multigenerational ties to the ranch, as with my own family, strengthened my cowboy pride. The program also allowed me to fulfill my adventurous side, visiting Sydney's iconic Opera House and hiking through New Zealand's breathtaking landscapes.  

For any young rancher seeking an opportunity to serve our agriculture community while broadening your worldview, I encourage applying for the Seagoing Cowboys program. You won't regret the unforgettable people you'll meet or places you'll see. Most of all, you'll return home with a renewed passion for ranching and its importance around the globe. There is no better way to spend a year than immersed in ranch work and culture in some of the most beautiful places on earth. I assure you this experience will stay with you for a lifetime.

essay_title: In the article “Driverless Cars are Coming,” the author presents both positive and negative aspects of driverless cars. Using details from the article, create an argument for or against the development of these cars. Be sure to include: your position on driverless cars; appropriate details from the article that support your position; an introduction, a body, and a conclusion to your argumentative essay.
essay_text:
The Development of Driverless Cars

While driverless cars hold promise for convenience and safety, their widespread adoption also presents serious risks that require careful consideration. According to the article, proponents argue that these autonomous vehicles could significantly reduce traffic accidents caused by human error. Without drivers to become distracted, tired, or impaired, traffic collisions may decrease. This contributes to the view that driverless cars could save thousands of lives each year. 

However, the article also notes several disadvantages. Fully removing human control from the vehicle raises privacy and security issues. Our personal information and travel patterns could become vulnerable to hackers without manual driving separating us from an interconnected system. Additionally, algorithms may sometimes struggle with unpredictable, complex traffic situations in a way human judgment handles more flexibly. If not thoroughly tested, flaws could emerge when driverless cars interact with other vehicles or unexpected road conditions.

Most concerning is that despite promises of improved safety, the bugs and oversights of a new technology are difficult to foresee. While many lives may eventually be saved, lives could also be lost during an extended period of refinement as autonomous vehicles and human-driven cars share the road. A single highly publicized accident caused by a software or hardware malfunction could erode public trust and acceptance of the new technology. Considering the difficulties of anticipating every scenario on public roads, widespread implementation may happen before complete reliability is achieved. 

In conclusion, while the long-term benefits of driverless cars are compelling, more research and testing is still required before allowing their full adoption. Privacy and security issues also warrant addressing. A gradual, cautious approach that blends human and autonomous control seems wisest to avoid serious risks during this transition period. Only after autonomous systems can demonstrably perform as safely as human drivers in all typical conditions should we consider them ready for widespread use without human supervision. Safety must remain the top priority as this new technology continues to develop.

essay_title:
Your principal is considering changing school policy so that students may not participate in sports or other activities unless they have at least a grade B average. Many students have a grade C average.
She would like to hear the students' views on this possible policy change. Write a letter to your principal arguing for or against requiring at least a grade B average to participate in sports or other activities. Be sure to support your arguments with specific reasons.
essay_text:
Dear Principal Smith, 

I am writing to express my views on the possible policy change to require students to have at least a B average in order to participate in sports and extracurricular activities. While maintaining good grades is important, implementing this policy could have some unintended negative consequences that I hope you will consider.

Requiring a B average will exclude many students who currently maintain a C average from being able to participate in the very activities that help them succeed academically. For many students, being involved in sports, clubs, or other extracurriculars provides motivation to do well in school and learn time management skills. It also gives them an outlet for reducing stress so they can focus better in class. Taking these activities away could potentially cause grades to suffer even more for some. 

Additionally, activities are important for students' mental and physical health. They help promote teamwork, leadership, confidence and overall well-being. For students who struggle more in the classroom, sports and clubs may be the one thing keeping them engaged and happy at school. Removing this could negatively impact their enjoyment of and commitment to their education.

While maintaining a B average shows commitment to academic success, a C average should not preclude students from having balanced involvement in school. Most colleges and employers will consider a student's complete application, including talents, interests and character demonstrated through extracurricular participation. Rather than require a B, perhaps participation could come with the requirement of maintaining a C average or higher, attending mandatory study sessions, or maintaining good behavior and attendance. This would hold students accountable without shutting the door on activities that are important for both performance in school as well as overall development.  

I strongly believe that keeping opportunities available to students who work hard and represent the school well, even if their grades are not perfect, is beneficial to students and the school community as a whole. Thank you for considering these perspectives and being open to ensuring policies support all students' well-being and success. Please let me know if I can discuss this topic further.

Sincerely,
[Your name]

essay_title: You have just read the article, 'A Cowboy Who Rode the Waves.' Luke's participation in the Seagoing Cowboys program allowed him to experience adventures and visit many unique places. Using information from the article, write an argument from Luke's point of view convincing others to participate in the Seagoing Cowboys program. Be sure to include: reasons to join the program; details from the article to support Luke's claims; an introduction, a body, and a conclusion to your essay.
essay_text:
Life on the open water awakened parts of my soul I never knew existed. Waking each morning to endless blue horizons and the crash of waves against our vessel's hull filled me with peace. Yet it also lit a fire for exploration that drove me to every new coast and port. I witnessed landscapes both rugged and serene, from rocky cliffs pounded by surf to tiny tropical islands ringed with white sand. Working alongside crews from all walks of life opened my eyes to diverse cultures I'd never encounter at home. Whether mending nets in a Portuguese harbor or sharing songs around the fire with Norwegian fishermen, each connection made me feel part of something larger than my little corner of the world. 

Perhaps most rewarding was developing new skills to tackle each trial the sea threw our way. As a cowboy used to open skies, climbing the rigging high above the deck or battling 30-foot waves tested my courage. Yet with guidance from veteran seamen, I learned to read cloud formations, tie knots even the horses back home couldn't untangle, and work shifts through tropical storms that would make the stoutest soul quake. Facing each mountainous swell as if it were a bucking longhorn taught me resilience I cherish to this day. Now whenever challenges arise, I hear the crash of the ocean wind and feel its steadying strength within me.

For any soul longing for adventures beyond imagination, look no further than Seagoing Cowboys. This program opened my eyes, my heart, and strengthened my spirit in ways no lone steer wrestling ever could. The bonds and skills I gained will stay with me forever, as will memories of inland seas more beautiful than any sunset over the prairie. I left a cowboy, but returned a citizen of the world, forever changed for the better. This, my friends, is a journey worth your while. The sea calls - will you answer?

essay_title: Some schools require students to complete summer projects to assure they continue learning during their break. Should these summer projects be teacher-designed or student-designed? Take a position on this question. Support your response with reasons and specific examples.
essay_text:
Schools should allow for more student-designed summer projects rather than having all projects teacher-designed. Giving students more autonomy and choice in their education can foster greater engagement and creativity. When students have a role in choosing the focus of their summer learning, they are more invested in the work. 

Teacher-designed projects do ensure students cover certain topics or skills during the summer months. However, imposing one-size-fits-all assignments generally finds less enthusiasm from learners. Students have diverse interests and motivations, so a more personalized approach works better. Allowing student input into designing their own project gives them ownership over their learning. They can explore an area they truly find intriguing rather than just checking boxes on a generic assignment.

When students get to choose what they study, they are more likely to delve deeper. They will work harder on a project about a subject they selected themselves versus something a teacher arbitrarily assigned. Students may come up with novel ideas a teacher would never envision. Their creative solutions to demonstrating understanding can push learning in new directions. Seeing academic topics through the fresh eyes of youth brings new perspectives. 

Of course, giving full freedom without any guardrails risks students choosing easy tasks that don't challenge them. A balanced model provides student choice within certain parameters set by instructors. Teachers could suggest broad topics aligned with curriculum but allow for customization. They should offer guidance and feedback as projects unfold. Such an individualized yet structured approach maximizes student agency while still meeting learning objectives over summer vacation. 

In summary, teacher-designed projects alone cannot inspire every student. Giving learners a say in their summertime education through more student-directed assignments engages them more actively and yields deeper understanding. Schools should adopt policies empowering students as autonomous drivers of their own knowledge growth during breaks from the classroom.

essay_title: Some schools require students to complete summer projects to assure they continue learning during their break. Should these summer projects be teacher-designed or student-designed? Take a position on this question. Support your response with reasons and specific examples.
essay_text:
While both teacher-designed and student-designed summer projects have benefits, I believe student-designed projects are generally more valuable for students' learning and development. Here are a few reasons why:

Student autonomy and ownership. When students are given the opportunity to choose their own summer project topics based on their individual interests, it fosters creativity, autonomy and a sense of ownership over their work. They are more intrinsically motivated to dedicate time and effort when exploring an area they genuinely find engaging or meaningful. This can nurture lifelong learning habits. 

Tailored learning experience. Teacher-designed projects aim to be one-size-fits-all assignments, but students learn in diverse ways and have varied strengths, weaknesses and curiosity. Student-directed projects allow each learner to structure an experience tailored to their unique skills, needs and passion. This personalized approach is optimal for retaining and applying knowledge beyond standardized curricula. 

Practical life skills. By having autonomy in designing their plan of action, students practice critical real-world skills like goal-setting, time management, research strategies and self-motivation - abilities vital for academic and career success. This better prepares them for independent lifelong learning compared to externally imposed agendas. Student-driven projects foster independence, responsibility and self-reliance. 

However, teachers can still provide guidance for student projects through topic suggestions, parameters for scope, format requirements or due dates. A balanced approach of student choice within an supportive framework maximizes engagement and educational impact. Overall, structuring summer work as student-designed gives learners ownership over the learning process and opportunity to follow curiosity, key drivers for inspiration and achievement.

essay_title: You have read the article 'Unmasking the Face on Mars.' Imagine you are a scientist at NASA discussing the Face with someone who thinks it was created by aliens. Using information in the article, write an argumentative essay to convince someone that the Face is just a natural landform.Be sure to include: claims to support your argument that the Face is a natural landform; evidence from the article to support your claims; an introduction, a body, and a conclusion to your argumentative essay.
essay_text:
The Natural Formation of the "Face on Mars"

Many viewpoints exist regarding the so-called "Face on Mars." While some see evidence of extraterrestrial involvement, a closer examination reveals the Face is most likely a result of natural geological processes. 

Several pieces of evidence from the article support the notion that the Face is a mundane landform rather than an alien construction. First, images from newer Mars orbiters with higher resolution show the Face lacks distinguishing features one would expect of an intelligent construction. Its shape is vague and ambiguous, resembling a human face only from certain angles. Up close, it resembles an eroded mesa or hill more than a sculpture. 

Second, the materials it is composed of - sandstone and other sedimentary rocks - were formed by natural environmental factors like wind and rain erosion over millions of years. These are the same rock types that make up other mesas and hills in the region with no supposed "faces." The reddish iron oxide color is also common across the Martian surface and reveals nothing unusual about its composition. 

Finally, details from photos of surrounding areas indicate the Face is actually part of a naturally-formed cliff or hill. Its outline is determined by the bedding planes in which the sediments were laid down over eons, and it aligns with the general topography. These geological features take forms that sometimes resemble recognizable objects by chance alone.  

In conclusion, while an intriguing coincidence, scientific analysis of photos and context reveals the "Face on Mars" is quite plainly a natural rock formation shaped by normal environmental processes over immense timescales. Absent clear evidence of artificial construction, the safest conclusion is that no anomalous intelligence was involved in its formation. It remains a testament to the proclivity of the human mind to perceive recognizable patterns, even where none objectively exist. For these evidence-based reasons, I must conclude the face is a product of nature, not aliens.

essay_title: Some schools require students to complete summer projects to assure they continue learning during their break. Should these summer projects be teacher-designed or student-designed? Take a position on this question. Support your response with reasons and specific examples.
essay_text:
While both teacher-designed and student-designed summer projects have benefits, student-designed projects are generally preferable as they allow for more creativity, interest, and personal growth. 

When teachers design projects, they ensure students are reviewing important course content and topics from the previous year. This helps protect against skill and knowledge loss over summer break. However, teacher-designed projects risk feeling mandatory or like 'more homework' to students. They provide less freedom and motivation for deep learning depending on a student's individual interests.

Student-designed projects, on the other hand, give students autonomy to explore topics they find engaging and worthwhile. This type of intrinsic motivation leads to higher quality work and better retention of information as students learn about things they genuinely want to learn about. When students have ownership over their projects, they are more likely to spend additional time working to learn beyond what is strictly required. 

Of course, student-designed projects would still benefit from some teacher guidance to help students set appropriate and achievable goals. They could also touch on major curriculum areas to still retain relevance. However, the flexibility of student-driven projects allows each individual to grow in areas they find particularly fascinating or applicable to their goals. Requiring summer-long projects is reasonable to promote continuous learning, but letting students have a hand in choosing their focus tends to result in superior positive outcomes.

In conclusion, while both student-designed and teacher-designed summer projects can help students retain academic skills, student-designed options are preferable as they cultivate more meaningful engagement, creativity, and personal development for each learner over summer break. With some guidance, student-directed projects can still assure coverage of core educational areas while empowering more intrinsic and self-sustaining motivation for learning outside of the classroom.

essay_title: Some schools offer distance learning as an option for students to attend classes from home by way of online or video conferencing. Do you think students would benefit from being able to attend classes from home? Take a position on this issue. Support your response with reasons and examples.
essay_text:
While distance learning offers some benefits, I do not believe students would fully benefit from being able to attend all classes from home. There are several reasons why attending school in-person is important for student development and learning. 

One of the main advantages often cited for distance learning is flexibility - it allows students to learn on their own schedule and balance school with other commitments like work or family responsibilities. However, learning effectively requires structure and routine. Being in a regular classroom environment promotes time management, discipline and focus that is harder to maintain while studying at home. It also makes it easier for teachers to gauge student understanding and provide support in real time.

Another concern is the potential for distraction. Most home environments are not conducive to focused study for extended periods, as students may be interrupted by siblings, chores, TVs or other devices. It is difficult for young people to avoid temptations and multi-task while learning. The school setting removes these distractions to better hold students' attention. 

Social interaction is also an important part of education. Schools provide opportunities to collaborate, debate ideas and develop social skills—skills that are becoming increasingly valuable in today's world. Distance learning can make it harder for students to build relationships with peers and teachers. The social aspects of shared learning experiences are largely lost. This interaction is important for motivation and emotional well-being as well.

While distance options may supplement in-person classes, conducting all classes remotely would not fully replicate the myriad benefits of attending school in-person. A blended model balancing both approaches could allow flexibility while still promoting focused learning, social skills and student development. Overall, attending school is important for students' academic achievement and growth into well-rounded individuals.

essay_title: In "The Challenge of Exploring Venus," the author suggests studying Venus is a worthy pursuit despite the dangers it presents. Using details from the article, write an essay evaluating how well the author supports this idea. Be sure to include: a claim that evaluates how well the author supports the idea that studying Venus is a worthy pursuit despite the dangers; an explanation of the evidence from the article that supports your claim; an introduction, a body, and a conclusion to your essay.
essay_text:
Studying Venus is Indeed a Worthy Pursuit

The author presents a compelling case for why studying Venus is a worthy pursuit despite the dangers involved. The key evidence used to support this idea revolves around the potential scientific discoveries that could be made through close observation of Venus. According to the article, Venus remains mysterious in many ways and could yield insights about Earth's climate and atmosphere. By braving the harsh conditions, scientists may learn valuable lessons that enhance understanding of planetary evolution and climate change. 

Several details back up the potential for scientific progress. Venus' dense atmosphere and extreme surface temperatures remain poorly understood. The article notes discoveries could advance knowledge of atmospheric dynamics and greenhouse effects. Comparisons between Earth and Venus may provide perspective on how habitable conditions develop. The potential to learn about volcanic activity through radar mapping is also mentioned. Each of these avenues represent opportunities to gain useful geological and meteorological data through Venus exploration.

While facing 494 degree Celsius temperatures and a crushing atmosphere 96 times denser than Earth's does present obvious dangers, the author argues the rewards outweigh the risks. Careful planning and use of hardier probes and robots can minimize hazards to scientists. Overall, the evidence presented suggests studying Venus could significantly expand comprehension of planetary science issues in a way that benefits not just knowledge itself but also conditions here on Earth. For these reasons, the author makes a strong, evidence-based case that braving Venus' Hellish environment is absolutely a worthy scientific effort. Though hazardous, the potential discoveries clearly demonstrate the value of further exploring our closest planetary neighbor.

essay_title: You have just read the article, 'A Cowboy Who Rode the Waves.' Luke's participation in the Seagoing Cowboys program allowed him to experience adventures and visit many unique places. Using information from the article, write an argument from Luke's point of view convincing others to participate in the Seagoing Cowboys program. Be sure to include: reasons to join the program; details from the article to support Luke's claims; an introduction, a body, and a conclusion to your essay.
essay_text:
The Open Seas Await

Growing up on a ranch in Wyoming, I always dreamed of adventure beyond the wide-open plains. When I learned of the Seagoing Cowboys program, I knew this was my chance to explore the unknown. For over a year now, I have traveled the oceans as a member of this unique program. Each new destination has filled me with wonder and given me stories to last a lifetime. 

The Seagoing Cowboys allow participants to experience cultures unlike any back home on the ranch. On my journeys, I have visited bustling ports in Asia and quaint fishing villages in the South Pacific, gaining new perspectives on the world. Living aboard the ships also fosters close friendships with fellow cowboys from around the country. Even simple tasks like mending sails or preparing meals take on new meaning when shared with those who have also traded their horses for the high seas.

Most rewarding of all is the independence the program instills. As a seagoing cowboy, I have commanded watches alone and learned to navigate treacherous reefs. Facing storms hundreds of miles from the nearest port is exhilarating rather than frightening, knowing I have the skills to bring my ship to safety. This level of responsibility at a young age has built confidence I never could have gained elsewhere. After surviving difficult conditions at sea, I feel ready to take on any challenge on land. 

For those longing for adventure beyond the ordinary, I encourage you to join us as Seagoing Cowboys. You will gain knowledge and experiences to last a lifetime by trading your stirrups for a life aboard ship. The open ocean offers possibilities too numerous to imagine, waiting for the bold among us to make new discoveries around every bend. I promise you won't find a program better suited to cultivate independence and teach lifelong skills. So cast off your lines and set sail - the seas are calling!

essay_title:
Your principal is considering changing school policy so that students may not participate in sports or other activities unless they have at least a grade B average. Many students have a grade C average.
She would like to hear the students' views on this possible policy change. Write a letter to your principal arguing for or against requiring at least a grade B average to participate in sports or other activities. Be sure to support your arguments with specific reasons.
essay_text:
Dear Principal Johnson, 

I am writing to express my views on the possible policy change to require students to have at least a grade B average in order to participate in sports and other extracurricular activities. I believe this would be an unfair restriction that could discourage many students from getting involved. 

While maintaining good grades is important, requiring a B average could prevent participation by students who are working hard but still earning mostly C's. Being part of a team or club is how some students stay motivated to do well in their other classes. Taking away that outlet could actually cause grades to suffer rather than improve for those on the borderline. 

Participation teaches valuable life lessons like time management, leadership, responsibility and working with others toward a common goal. These skills are just as important as what we learn in the classroom. Not everyone excels equally in every subject, but they should not be excluded from other learning experiences that could help develop strengths in other areas.

Lowering the minimum GPA would still ensure students are passing their classes while keeping opportunities available that may inspire them to try harder. Some extra time spent on activities could even help relieve academic stress. Please consider allowing students with a C average or higher to be eligible rather than restricting many motivated students who just need more practice in some subjects. I believe this is a fairer approach that benefits more of the student body.

Thank you for considering our perspective. Let me know if you would like me to elaborate on any part of my argument.

essay_title: Write a letter to your state senator in which you argue in favor of keeping the Electoral College or changing to election by popular vote for the president of the United States. Use the information from the texts in your essay. Manage your time carefully so that you can read the passages; plan your response; write your response; and revise and edit your response. Be sure to include a claim; address counterclaims; use evidence from multiple sources; and avoid overly relying on one source. Your response should be in the form of a multiparagraph essay. Write your response in the space provided.
essay_text:
Dear Senator, 

I am writing to you today to express my opinion on whether the United States should keep the Electoral College system or change to a popular vote for electing the president. This is an important issue that deserves careful consideration.

The Electoral College system has some benefits. It encourages candidates to build wider geographic coalitions and avoid focusing only on highly populated areas. This helps represent the diverse interests of our large nation. However, it can result in a president being elected despite losing the nationwide popular vote. This has happened a few times in our history, most recently in 2000 and 2016. It undermines the principle of one person, one vote that is central to our democratic system. 

Supporters argue the popular vote could also discourage candidates from visiting smaller states and encourage higher voter turnout in big states. But the popular vote seems more fair and aligned with American democratic values. Every vote would truly count equally.
