Others who pick up litter in the local park enjoy beautifying the area and protecting the environment. Community service undoubtedly makes a positive impact.

However, requiring all students to volunteer takes away their freedom to choose how to spend their time outside of school. Not all students have the same interests or strengths when it comes to service. For some, extracurricular activities like sports, arts or academic clubs are a higher priority and how they prefer to contribute. Of course students should be encouraged to help their community if they are able to and interested. But for those with many commitments already, an unchosen obligation could cause resentment. 

A better approach may be to offer community service as an option for students to gain credit, rather than a universal rule. This keeps the door open for those inspired to help while respecting other activities or priorities of each individual. Education should balance requirements with allowing student choice whenever possible in my view. 

In conclusion, while community service undoubtedly benefits those served and can be a positive experience, requiring it for all removes student freedom and risks compromising their motivation to help. For these reasons, I do not think it should be mandatory school-wide, but offered as an optional way for dedicated students to contribute. Please let me know if you have any other questions.

Sincerely, 
[Your name]

essay_title: Some schools offer distance learning as an option for students to attend classes from home by way of online or video conferencing. Do you think students would benefit from being able to attend classes from home? Take a position on this issue. Support your response with reasons and examples.
essay_text:
While distance learning provides flexibility that appeals to some students, I believe that attending traditional in-person classes results in better educational and social outcomes for most students. Here are a few reasons why:

First, in-person classes allow for more substantive teacher-student interaction. Teachers are better able to gauge students' understanding through body language, eye contact and spontaneous question-answering. They can also provide more individualized attention to students who appear confused or struggling with a concept. Distance learning makes these real-time interactions more difficult. 

Second, attending physical classes fosters collaboration and teamwork. In a classroom setting, students can easily turn to classmates sitting nearby to ask questions, discuss assignments, and work through problems together. Distance learning doesn't support this spontaneous group work as well. The social aspect of learning from and helping one's peers should not be underestimated.

Third, being present in a classroom helps students develop discipline, time management and focus. It's easier for students' attention to wander or procrastinate online assignments at home compared to being physically seated in a classroom. This structure is important for developing strong study habits that will serve students well in future educational pursuits and careers. 

Finally, school provides important social development for students. Beyond academics, in-person classes allow for socializing, interacting with diverse people, resolving conflicts, and learning social and emotional skills. For most adolescents and teenagers, this socialization with their peers is as important as the academic content. Distance learning cannot fully replace these important social learning opportunities.

In conclusion, while distance learning has its advantages for flexibility, traditional in-person classes offer significantly better educational and developmental outcomes for students due to increased interaction, collaboration, structure and socialization. For the average student, attending classes on a physical campus rather than from home would likely be more beneficial. Exceptions could be considered on a case-by-case basis for students with special circumstances. But in general, in-person schooling provides the well-rounded experience that serves students best.

essay_title: In the article “Driverless Cars are Coming,” the author presents both positive and negative aspects of driverless cars. Using details from the article, create an argument for or against the development of these cars. Be sure to include: your position on driverless cars; appropriate details from the article that support your position; an introduction, a body, and a conclusion to your argumentative essay.
essay_text:
The Development of Driverless Cars

While driverless cars present many potential benefits, their widespread adoption also raises serious safety and ethical concerns that require careful consideration. According to the article "Driverless Cars are Coming," autonomous vehicles could reduce traffic accidents by taking human error out of the driving experience. However, they may also struggle with unpredictable situations that human judgment handles instinctively. Overall the technology remains untested on a large scale.  

A key benefit discussed is reduced accidents, as the article notes that human error causes over 90% of crashes. Driverless cars use sensors and software and should not face issues like distraction, drunkenness or fatigue. Yet many edge cases may confuse even advanced AI. Unexpected obstacles like fallen trees after storms may be tricky to recognize without experience. Pedestrians or animals moving erratically could also vex sensors. While accidents may drop on highways, more complex scenarios in cities remain challenging to program for.

Moreover, ethical dilemmas abound. In a crash situation, should the car aim to protect its passengers no matter what, even if it means harming others? How do programmers assign relative values to different lives in such a calculation? Without perfect foresight, accidents may happen due to losing control or system failures. The legal liability in these situations also requires definition.

Overall the technology holds promise if developed prudently. More testing in controlled environments and with backup drivers can help identify shortcomings. Regulations must also anticipate ethical questions and assign responsibilities clearly. While driverless cars may offer future benefits, their risks require thorough consideration and oversight to avoid unintended consequences on public roads. For these reasons, a cautious approach that factors in both promise and perils seems wisest.

essay_title: You have read the article 'Unmasking the Face on Mars.' Imagine you are a scientist at NASA discussing the Face with someone who thinks it was created by aliens. Using information in the article, write an argumentative essay to convince someone that the Face is just a natural landform.Be sure to include: claims to support your argument that the Face is a natural landform; evidence from the article to support your claims; an introduction, a body, and a conclusion to your argumentative essay.
essay_text:
The Face on Mars: A Natural Phenomenon 

Many people speculate that the Face on Mars was created by intelligent lifeforms. However, evidence clearly shows it is a natural landform formed through geological processes over time. 

The article provides compelling evidence that the Face is not an artificial structure. It notes that images at higher resolutions reveal no signs of artificial construction such as symmetry or complex designs. Instead, it appears to be an entirely random arrangement of landforms that only looks like a face when viewed at a certain low angle and resolution. All close-up pictures confirm it has irregular shapes and slopes characteristic of natural erosion over eons rather than artificial construction. 

Additionally, Mars has experienced extensive volcanic and weathering activity that could easily form such patterns through completely natural causes. The Face's mesas, hills and valleys align with the surrounding geology. It is located in a region dense with similar eroded landforms, showing it evolved similarly through environmental exposure rather than intelligent design. The article also notes similar patterns created on Earth through natural weathering alone.

While pareidolia makes us see familiar patterns where none exist, the evidence is clear that the Face on Mars is purely a product of planetary geological processes over millions of years, rather than alien intervention. Its appearance aligns perfectly with what we would expect from an irregular, naturally forming landform on another planet. Though mysterious at a distance, up-close analysis confirms it is geologically indistinct from the surrounding landscape and shows no signs of artificial environment-altering construction. Therefore, the Face on Mars is without a doubt a natural, non-artificial landform formed by the forces of nature alone.

essay_title: When people ask for advice, they sometimes talk to more than one person. Explain why seeking multiple opinions can help someone make a better choice. Use specific details and examples in your response.
essay_text:
Seeking multiple opinions when making an important choice or decision is beneficial for a few key reasons. First, getting different perspectives allows you to consider aspects of the choice you may not have thought of on your own. Different people will have had different experiences that shape their views, so hearing more than one side can help highlight both pros and cons you may have overlooked. 

Secondly, conflicting opinions force you to really examine your own feelings and rationale more closely. When people disagree on a choice, you have to think critically about why each perspective makes its case. This self-reflection helps ensure the factors most important to you personally are prioritized in your final decision. You can weigh opinions against your own values and priorities.

A third reason multiple opinions are valuable is that no one person has all the answers. Even well-meaning friends and family see things only from their own point of view. Collecting several perspectives increases the chances of getting guidance that aligns with reality. One advisor might miss something another could catch. The convergence of consistent advice from different sources builds confidence that the consensus view has merit. 

Finally, taking time to consider multiple opinions shows good decision-making. It demonstrates you are a thoughtful, careful person who does not make important choices lightly. Consulting others is more mature than acting hastily on an initial gut reaction. The process of comparing varied viewpoints also gives you stronger justification for your ultimate decision if questions arise later. Weighing a diversity of advice helps ensure the choice you make is well-informed and in your best long-term interests.

In conclusion, seeking multiple perspectives provides distinct advantages over relying on a single opinion when facing significant decisions. Hearing from more than one trusted advisor leads to choices that have been scrutinized from numerous angles and therefore have a greater chance of being the right one for your own unique circumstances and priorities. Multiple inputs result in wiser, more well-reasoned selections.

essay_title: When people ask for advice, they sometimes talk to more than one person. Explain why seeking multiple opinions can help someone make a better choice. Use specific details and examples in your response.
essay_text:
Seeking multiple opinions when making an important decision or asking for advice is usually a good idea. Talking to more than one person allows you to get different perspectives on the situation. Each person you consult might know something the others do not or have had unique experiences that provide valuable insights. Getting a variety of viewpoints helps ensure you don't miss important factors to consider or unintentionally narrow your focus too much based on the opinion of just one person. 

Family and friends can give helpful advice but may be biased based on their relationship to you. Speaking to more impartial sources expands the range of opinions. Someone outside your inner circle is less emotionally invested and may notice things those closest to you overlook. Balance is important when deciding between listening mostly to friends who want to support you emotionally versus strangers who offer a less biased analysis. Considering both types of advice together tends to yield the wisest choice. 

Comparing what different people say can also help identify common themes or areas of disagreement. This highlights which issues or factors elicited consistent versus varying reactions. Useful information often emerges through exploring reasons behind disagreements too. Investigating opposing views challenges assumptions and prevents you from dismissing certain options prematurely without due consideration. Seeing an issue from multiple perspectives is key to making a fully informed choice.

In summary, seeking advice from more than one trusted source increases the likelihood of making the choice that fits your unique situation the best. No single person knows everything relevant to a complex decision, but together multiple advisors can provide a well-rounded pool of input to draw from. Taking the time to gather varied opinions pays off in helping select the alternative most likely to provide the results you want in the long run.

essay_title: In "The Challenge of Exploring Venus," the author suggests studying Venus is a worthy pursuit despite the dangers it presents. Using details from the article, write an essay evaluating how well the author supports this idea. Be sure to include: a claim that evaluates how well the author supports the idea that studying Venus is a worthy pursuit despite the dangers; an explanation of the evidence from the article that supports your claim; an introduction, a body, and a conclusion to your essay.
essay_text:
Evaluating Venus as a Worthy Pursuit Despite Its Dangers 

The author makes a compelling case for studying Venus despite the planet's hazardous conditions. In "The Challenge of Exploring Venus," key evidence supports the claim that Venus exploration is worthwhile in advancing scientific discovery, even with the risks involved. 

Several details demonstrate how studying Venus could lead to important insights. Venus' similar size, mass, and early evolutionary history to Earth suggest it may yield clues about Earth's primordial atmosphere and climate. Comparative analysis of their evolution may illuminate how Earth avoided a runaway greenhouse effect. Additionally, Venus' surface indicates potential volcanic activity, allowing scientists to better understand geological processes on terrestrial planets. These opportunities to expand our knowledge of planetary science make facing Venus' challenges worthwhile.

Of course, Venus' hostile environment consisting of extreme heat and acidity present daunting obstacles. Its dense, toxic atmosphere and surface temperatures hot enough to melt lead immediately threaten any equipment or life attempting to land or operate there. However, the author notes that technological progress enables exploring even the harshest planetary surfaces more safely. Remote sensing like aerial platforms and body heaters could enable studying Venus from a safer distance, minimizing direct exposure risks. With care and innovation to overcome Venus' dangers, valuable scientific returns could result from missions exploring our neighboring planet's secrets. 

In conclusion, while Venus poses serious hazards, the article convincingly shows how its exploration could significantly contribute to understanding Earth and terrestrial planetary evolution. Technological advances may allow circumventing surface dangers, realizing Venus' potential to answer compelling questions about comparable rocky worlds. Considering these informative scientific gains, braving Venus' atmosphere and conditions seems a risk appropriately taken to further knowledge of our corner of the cosmos. The author makes a sound case that studying Venus merits undertaking despite the perils involved.

essay_title: You have just read the article, 'A Cowboy Who Rode the Waves.' Luke's participation in the Seagoing Cowboys program allowed him to experience adventures and visit many unique places. Using information from the article, write an argument from Luke's point of view convincing others to participate in the Seagoing Cowboys program. Be sure to include: reasons to join the program; details from the article to support Luke's claims; an introduction, a body, and a conclusion to your essay.
essay_text:
Participating in Unforgettable Adventures  

As a lifelong cowboy, I've always enjoyed exploring new places from the saddle. But when I learned about the Seagoing Cowboys program, I knew this would be a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to see the world from the sea. Over my six months with the program, I experienced more adventure than I ever thought possible! Everyday was a new challenge as we worked alongside crews on tall ships, caring for the vessels as they navigated endless oceans. I visited major ports in five countries across two continents, witnessing diverse cultures I previously only read about. 

One of the most memorable parts of the program was helping to sail an antique wooden schooner from England to France. For weeks we battled high winds and treacherous waves, relying on teamwork as we stood watch through the night. Just when I thought seasickness would get the best of me, the sun would rise to reveal new stunning coastlines on the horizon. Landing in lovely French harbors after our voyage felt like an achievement few landlocked folks ever taste. The skills I gained through such trials have stayed with me, reminding me that I can overcome any obstacle with determination.

Beyond the adventures, I also learned so much about history, engineering and different ways of life. On another tall ship journey, our erudite captain taught us about astronomy and navigation techniques used by early explorers. In Australia, I gained insights into Aboriginal culture through conversations with locals. The program really opened my eyes to the world beyond my Texas ranch. To this day, I still keep in touch with friendships forged across borders. 

If you long for adventure and crave visiting new places, I can't recommend the Seagoing Cowboys program highly enough. The six months I spent sailing to far-flung ports are ones I will forever treasure. While it may push you outside your comfort zone at times, you'll develop skills and make lifelong memories that will stay with you wherever the tide may take you. The wonders, skills and stories I gained have made all the hard work at sea more than worth it. I promise this program will provide unforgettable experiences that broaden your horizons beyond any imaginary.

essay_title: You have just read the article, 'A Cowboy Who Rode the Waves.' Luke's participation in the Seagoing Cowboys program allowed him to experience adventures and visit many unique places. Using information from the article, write an argument from Luke's point of view convincing others to participate in the Seagoing Cowboys program. Be sure to include: reasons to join the program; details from the article to support Luke's claims; an introduction, a body, and a conclusion to your essay.
essay_text:
Participating in Unique Adventures

As a lifelong cowboy, I was eager to try something new and exciting when I learned about the Seagoing Cowboys program. Having grown up riding horses on the range, I was ready for an adventure that would allow me to see more of the world. The opportunity to take my skills out on the open water as a Seagoing Cowboy was truly one of a kind. 

There were so many reasons the program appealed to me. First and foremost, I would get to visit beautiful, remote locations that few people ever see. As the article described, our group traveled to places like a lighthouse off the coast of Maine and rocky shores along the Pacific Northwest. As someone who has spent his life in wide-open spaces, seeing dramatic ocean vistas and seaside cliffs really opened my eyes to new landscapes. I also loved learning about the history of each place we stopped and getting a taste of local culture.

Another big draw was using my animal handling experience in a completely new setting. Herding cattle on a rocky boat was a real challenge that tested my skills in unexpected ways. Adapting my techniques on the unsteady deck taught me so much about working with livestock in all conditions. I felt an immense sense of accomplishment after each successful drive. The program also strengthened my problem-solving and leadership abilities as our group worked as a team on the high seas. 

Overall, participating in the Seagoing Cowboys program allowed me to grow both personally and professionally. I was pushed far outside my comfort zone but rewarded with breathtaking scenery and memories that I will forever treasure. For anyone wanting an adventure that is educational, rewarding, and totally unique, I highly recommend applying for this one-of-a-kind opportunity. The seas may be uncharted waters for a cowboy, but the voyage is absolutely worth it.

essay_title: Write a letter to your state senator in which you argue in favor of keeping the Electoral College or changing to election by popular vote for the president of the United States. Use the information from the texts in your essay. Manage your time carefully so that you can read the passages; plan your response; write your response; and revise and edit your response. Be sure to include a claim; address counterclaims; use evidence from multiple sources; and avoid overly relying on one source. Your response should be in the form of a multiparagraph essay. Write your response in the space provided.
essay_text:
Dear Senator,

I am writing to express my view that the United States should change from the Electoral College system to electing the president by popular vote. While the Electoral College was designed to give small states more influence, today's system can result in a president being elected despite losing the nationwide popular vote. This undermines the principle of one person, one vote and democratic fairness. 

Supporters of keeping the Electoral College argue that it encourages candidates to build broader coalitions and avoid focusing just on a few high population states. However, in recent elections we have seen candidates concentrate campaigning and advertising in only a handful of swing states that could vote either way. With a popular vote, every vote would matter equally and candidates would need to appeal to a broader range of citizens. It would encourage higher voter turnout nationwide rather than selective turnout in swing states.

It is also argued that the Electoral College system maintains the federal character of the election by giving small states more say. But in practice, the national popular vote winner almost always wins the Electoral College too. So the system does not significantly boost small states' influence. Furthermore, allocating electoral votes based on congressional districts in some states has politicized the redistricting process and led to instances of partisan gerrymandering to benefit one party. 

A nationwide popular vote would be a simpler, more straightforward and democratic process. It would ensure that the candidate preferred by the most Americans would become president. While changing to the popular vote may need an amendment, moving in this direction could help address concerns about how some recent elections have undermined faith in our democratic system. For these reasons, I believe moving to a national popular vote is a better approach and ensures that every valid vote has an equal say in choosing the president.

essay_title: Write an explanatory essay to inform fellow citizens about the advantages of limiting car usage. Your essay must be based on ideas and information that can be found in the passage set. Manage your time carefully so that you can read the passages; plan your response; write your response; and revise and edit your response. Be sure to use evidence from multiple sources; and avoid overly relying on one source. Your response should be in the form of a multiparagraph essay. Write your essay in the space provided.
essay_text:
Limiting car usage can provide significant benefits to both individuals and communities. While cars allow for flexibility and convenience, overreliance on personal vehicles has negative environmental, health, and social consequences. By reducing car trips when possible, citizens can help address these issues and improve quality of life.

One major advantage of limiting car usage is improved air quality and environmental health. Automobiles are a leading source of air pollution in many cities. Emissions from gasoline and diesel engines contain particulate matter and gases like carbon monoxide, nitrogen oxides, and volatile organic compounds that can cause respiratory illnesses. Reducing car trips lowers these harmful emissions and makes urban air cleaner to breathe. Citizen actions like using public transit, biking, or walking on short trips can collectively make a meaningful difference in curbing air pollution.

In addition, limiting car usage promotes active lifestyles and public health. Today physical inactivity is a serious issue, contributing to rising obesity and disease rates. Driving one's car even for short distances discourages walking and physical activity in daily life. Opting for alternative modes of transportation on feasible trips gives opportunities for light to moderate exercise through biking or walking. Regular physical activity, no matter how moderate, translates to tangible health benefits over time. Individual health improves while also reducing burdens on public medical systems. 

Socially, limiting car usage fosters closer-knit, walkable communities. Over-reliance on personal vehicles reduces social interactions and engagement within neighborhoods. Public spaces become dominated by traffic and parking instead of people. By contrast, alternative modes of travel encourage chance social encounters and a sense of shared public areas. Interacting with fellow community members on the street, in parks, and at local shops can help strengthen relationships and a sense of belonging. Vibrant, socially cohesive neighborhoods are a desirable asset for quality of life in any city.

In conclusion, limiting personal car usage produces clear advantages for both individuals and communities through improved environmental quality, health outcomes, and social well-being. While cars enable convenience, overreliance on them comes at high environmental and public costs. citizens can choose more sustainable options that support cleaner air, active lifestyles, and connected neighborhoods through alternative modes of transportation on feasible trips. Taking steps to drive less represents a positive action individuals can make to benefit communities and future generations.

essay_title: Write an explanatory essay to inform fellow citizens about the advantages of limiting car usage. Your essay must be based on ideas and information that can be found in the passage set. Manage your time carefully so that you can read the passages; plan your response; write your response; and revise and edit your response. Be sure to use evidence from multiple sources; and avoid overly relying on one source. Your response should be in the form of a multiparagraph essay. Write your essay in the space provided.
essay_text:
Limiting car usage provides many benefits for citizens and the environment. According to passage 1, reducing car trips could help alleviate traffic congestion in cities. With fewer vehicles on the road at peak times, travel would be more efficient for those who still need to drive. Public transit options could also see less delay if roads have lighter traffic. Passage 2 supports this by stating that traffic jams cost the economy large sums of money yearly due to lost productivity from wasted time spent in traffic. Limiting car usage would help reduce these economic losses. 

Another advantage outlined in passage 1 is improved air quality. Fewer automobiles on the road means less pollution from vehicle emissions. This would lead to healthier air for citizens to breathe. Children and those with respiratory issues would especially benefit. Passage 3 reinforces this point by explaining how traffic pollution has been linked to higher cancer and mortality rates. Reducing car usage could help lower these public health risks.

In addition, passage 1 notes environmental benefits such as less consumption of non-renewable fossil fuels and reduced greenhouse gas emissions. These effects are expanded on in passage 2, which discusses how automobile emissions are a leading cause of climate change. By driving less, citizens can help reduce carbon footprints and mitigate further global warming impacts. This protects natural environments and resources for future generations.

In summary, limiting car usage provides clear societal and environmental advantages. It can reduce traffic congestion, emissions and fuel use while boosting economic productivity and public health. Educating fellow citizens about these benefits could encourage more alternative and sustainable transportation choices that are better for communities and the planet. Convincing others to drive less will take an ongoing effort but reaps rewards for citizens and the environment alike.

essay_title: Some schools require students to complete summer projects to assure they continue learning during their break. Should these summer projects be teacher-designed or student-designed? Take a position on this question. Support your response with reasons and specific examples.
essay_text:
Whether summer projects for students should be teacher-designed or student-designed is an issue that has reasonable arguments on both sides. Teacher-designed projects allow schools to ensure students are retaining important academic concepts over the summer break. However, student-designed projects promote independence and allow greater flexibility for individual interests. On balance, I believe the best approach is a combination of the two options. 

There are benefits to having teachers design some mandatory projects for the summer. When schools craft the assignments, they can target specific subjects and skills they want students to practice and reinforce. This helps prevent academic regression over the months away from classes. Teachers know the curriculum and standards well, so their projects can be tailored to meet educational objectives. However, requiring only teacher-made work lacks student autonomy. It may not spark as much intrinsic motivation as letting students have some choice in what they study.

Allowing students to design some of their own projects addresses this issue. When students get to choose topics related to but extending beyond their normal classwork, it encourages independent learning tailored to their interests and strengths. This kind of independent exploration can foster deeper understanding and nurture innate curiosity. Having a mix of flexible guidelines rather than rigid requirements respects students' individuality. However, fully unguided free choice could result in some students doing little productive work without oversight. 

The best compromise is a blended approach that balances flexibility with structure. Students could choose from a selection of multi-week projects crafted by teachers, with room for some modification or supplemental assignments of the student's own design. This balances ensuring coverage of core skills with giving students ownership over some of their work. It promotes both skill-retention and independent growth. Short follow-up assignments from teachers could check progress without imposing rigid requirements. This balanced model would maximize learning potential and motivation for all students over the summer break.

essay_title: You have just read the article, 'A Cowboy Who Rode the Waves.' Luke's participation in the Seagoing Cowboys program allowed him to experience adventures and visit many unique places. Using information from the article, write an argument from Luke's point of view convincing others to participate in the Seagoing Cowboys program. Be sure to include: reasons to join the program; details from the article to support Luke's claims; an introduction, a body, and a conclusion to your essay.
essay_text:
The Open Seas Beckon 

As a lifelong cowboy from the dusty plains of Wyoming, I never imagined the adventures that awaited me when I joined the Seagoing Cowboys program. When I first heard about the opportunity to trade my horse for a tall ship and see new lands from the deck, I was intrigued but uncertain. However, the enriching experiences I've had since setting sail have convinced me of the program's immense value for any person with a spirit of discovery. 

Participating has allowed me to exercise my adventurous instincts while gaining knowledge and perspective. I've visited over a dozen countries across four continents, witnessing diverse cultures and landscapes unlike anything in my home state. Sailing through the Mediterranean under a warm sun or staring up at the Southern Lights dancing in the night sky are memories I'll always treasure. I've also learned valuable skills, assisting the crew with navigation, weather prediction, and seamanship. These responsibilities have boosted my confidence while introducing me to proud maritime traditions.

Perhaps most remarkably, the welcoming nature of crews and locals wherever the ship docks has reminded me of humanity's shared passion for fellowship. Whether breaking bread with fishermen in Greece or drumming with villagers in Tanzania, each encounter melts away differences in a celebration of our common hopes and dreams. I feel I have friends around the globe now, bonded by kindness and experience instead of nationality. 

My adventures on the tall ship have opened my eyes to the rich diversity of our world and strengthened my appreciation for other ways of life. I left home expecting waves but found fellowship and knowledge on the open seas. I know that any person who joins Seagoing Cowboys will return richer in spirit, with their horizons even farther than when they began. For the opportunity to broaden one's mind and worldview in such an immersive way, I say cast off your doubts and set sail - the experience awaits you.

essay_title: In the article "Making Mona Lisa Smile," the author describes how a new technology called the Facial Action Coding System enables computers to identify human emotions. Using details from the article, write an essay arguing whether the use of this technology to read the emotional expressions of students in a classroom is valuable.
essay_text:
Using Facial Action Coding System technology to read the emotional expressions of students in the classroom could provide some benefits but also raises serious privacy and ethical concerns. 

On one hand, this technology may help teachers gain insights into how their students are responding to lessons on an individual level. If a teacher knows that most students seem confused or bored during a particular part of a lesson, for example, they could adjust their teaching approach to improve comprehension. The technology could also help identify students who are struggling emotionally but might not speak up, so that teachers could check in and offer support. 

However, constantly monitoring students' facial expressions against their will would be an invasion of privacy that could undermine trust in the learning environment. Students should feel free to experience a full range of emotions without every reaction being recorded and analyzed. There are also concerns about misinterpreting facial cues or making assumptions without understanding the full context of students' lives. Labels based on facial scans could potentially do more harm than good if not used sensitively and ethically. 

Overall, while this technology offers potential benefits if used judiciously, the risks to student privacy and well-being are serious factors that need to be weighed. More discussion is needed around establishing guidelines for informed consent, data privacy, and ensuring the technology supplements but does not replace human judgment from teachers who know their students. Unless such issues are addressed comprehensively, the downsides of non-consensual emotional profiling may outweigh any advantages in most classroom applications.

essay_title: You have just read the article, 'A Cowboy Who Rode the Waves.' Luke's participation in the Seagoing Cowboys program allowed him to experience adventures and visit many unique places. Using information from the article, write an argument from Luke's point of view convincing others to participate in the Seagoing Cowboys program. Be sure to include: reasons to join the program; details from the article to support Luke's claims; an introduction, a body, and a conclusion to your essay.
essay_text:
Experiencing Adventures on the High Seas

Growing up on a cattle ranch in Texas, I always dreamed of adventure beyond the wide open plains. When I learned about the Seagoing Cowboys program, I knew this was my chance to explore the world while learning invaluable skills. The program allowed me to experience more in a few short months than most see in a lifetime. If you want excitement, adventure and opportunities to grow as a person, then the Seagoing Cowboys program is for you. 

Sailing on tall ships to exotic ports of call was simply amazing. I was in awe of the vastness of the open ocean and got a new perspective of the world from its seas. Visiting amazing places like the Caribbean and France was like something out of a storybook. I may have started in Texas, but I felt like a true citizen of the world by the end of my journey. The program also paired work with sightseeing, as we helped deliver cattle between continents just as historic traders once did. Lending a hand made the adventure even more rewarding and gave glimpses into cultures both similar to and different from my own.

In addition to international travel, I gained invaluable life skills. As a cowboy, I was accustomed to hard work but taking care of livestock on the high seas was a new challenge that built my resolve. I also had to learn seamanship, navigation, and how to work as a well-oiled crew, invaluable skills regardless of my future career path. Now I feel ready to take on any challenge that comes my way, on land or sea, thanks to pushing myself outside my comfort zone through the Seagoing Cowboys program.  

If you want to see the world from a truly unique perspective and build skills that will last a lifetime, join me and experience adventures that will stay with you forever through the Seagoing Cowboys program. Your steadfast spirit will be rewarded with international travel, cultural experiences and personal growth beyond imagination. I guarantee the journey will surpass even your loftiest expectations. What are you waiting for? Sign up today and let your seafaring adventures begin!

essay_title: Write a letter to your state senator in which you argue in favor of keeping the Electoral College or changing to election by popular vote for the president of the United States. Use the information from the texts in your essay. Manage your time carefully so that you can read the passages; plan your response; write your response; and revise and edit your response. Be sure to include a claim; address counterclaims; use evidence from multiple sources; and avoid overly relying on one source. Your response should be in the form of a multiparagraph essay. Write your response in the space provided.
essay_text:
Dear Senator, 

I am writing to express my view that the Electoral College system should be kept for electing the President of the United States. While moving to a popular vote seems appealing in some ways, I believe the Electoral College encourages greater voter participation and protects the interests of smaller states.

One concern about a popular vote is that it could discourage voter turnout, especially in states that are not considered swing states. Currently, candidates try to appeal to voters in competitive states, which encourages high voter participation in those locations. However, with a national popular vote, candidates may focus all their attention on heavily populated areas. This could reduce incentives for people in other parts of the country to vote. 

It is also important to remember that the United States was designed as a federal republic composed of individual state governments. The Electoral College system helps to balance state and national interests. Smaller population states rightfully worry that candidates would ignore their issues in a national popular vote. The current system guarantees that smaller states still have a meaningful say in presidential elections. This helps maintain the federal character of our system of government.

Of course, some critics argue that the Electoral College can result in a president being elected despite losing the nationwide popular vote. While this has happened a few times, it is a reflection of how candidates must build a nationwide coalition, not just win the most total votes. A nationwide plurality system may also have its flaws.

In conclusion, while the popular vote idea has some intuitive appeal, I believe the Electoral College overall serves our democratic process better by encouraging broad voter participation and respecting the interests of all states. It has worked reasonably well for over two centuries and remains the best system for presidential elections. I hope you will consider opposing any proposals to abandon it.

Thank you for your consideration. Let me know if you have any other questions.

Sincerely,
[Your name]

essay_title: In "The Challenge of Exploring Venus," the author suggests studying Venus is a worthy pursuit despite the dangers it presents. Using details from the article, write an essay evaluating how well the author supports this idea. Be sure to include: a claim that evaluates how well the author supports the idea that studying Venus is a worthy pursuit despite the dangers; an explanation of the evidence from the article that supports your claim; an introduction, a body, and a conclusion to your essay.
essay_text:
While studying Venus presents significant dangers, the author makes a compelling case that it remains a worthy scientific pursuit. The author supports this claim in several key ways. 

First, the author notes that Venus remains one of the most Earth-like planets in our solar system and could offer insights about the formation and evolution of terrestrial planets. Understanding atmospheres and climates on other worlds would help scientists better understand Earth's past and future. Venus' proximity also allows for relatively low-cost and frequent missions, increasing our chances of discovering new knowledge. These facts suggest studying Venus could reveal profoundly informative details about planetary science.

Second, the author details how technological and design developments have made recent missions safer and more durable, enabling researchers to withstand the extreme Venusian environment for longer periods. Past Soviet missions survived for only a few hours on the surface, but the proposed missions outlined could operate for over 30 days. Improved materials, redundancies and backup systems increase the likelihood of mission success and collecting valuable data despite dangers like the harsh climate. 

In conclusion, while Venus presents serious hazards, the potential scientific value of studying our sister planet through increased manned and unmanned missions is a worthy goal. Technological progress has opened the possibility for safer, longer term missions, and Venus' similarities to Earth mean it can illuminate fundamental questions about planetary science and habitability. The author builds a persuasive case that the dangers of exploring Venus are outweighed by the potential discoveries that could expand our understanding of worlds both within our own sollar system and beyond. For these reasons, pursuing the study of Venus is justified despite the challenges it poses.

essay_title:
Your principal is reconsidering the school's cell phone policy. She is considering two possible policies:
- Policy 1: Allow students to bring phones to school and use them during lunch periods and other free times, as long as the phones are turned off during class time.
- Policy 2: Do not allow students to have phones at school at all.
Write a letter to your principal convincing her which policy you believe is better. Support your position with specific reasons.
essay_text:
Dear Principal,

I am writing to respectfully provide my perspective on the school's cell phone policy options under consideration. Upon reviewing Policy 1 and Policy 2, I believe that Policy 1 is the better choice for our school. Here are a few reasons why:

Policy 1 allows limited and responsible cell phone use during free periods like lunch. For many students, having their phones during the school day provides a sense of safety and means of contacting family if needed. Banning phones altogether may cause undue stress or worry. Policy 1 balances this need for connection with the importance of focusing without distractions during class time.

Keeping phones put away during class under Policy 1 also sets students up for success. We want to foster an environment where learning can take place without technology serving as a distraction. However, an outright ban seems overly restrictive and could backfire by tempting some to secretly use their devices anyway. Policy 1 establishes clear rules that are reasonable for students to follow. 

Finally, Policy 1 is more reflective of the real world responsibilities most students will face after graduation. A full phone ban does not adequately prepare students for integrating technology into work and school life in a focused, structured way. Policy 1’s limited hours of permission help students practice effective self-monitoring and time management with their devices.

In summary, I believe Policy 1 is the optimal choice as it considers students' needs while also supporting focus during academic hours. Thank you for thoughtfully considering my perspective on this important topic. Please let me know if you need any additional information.

Sincerely,
[Your name]

essay_title: Some schools offer distance learning as an option for students to attend classes from home by way of online or video conferencing. Do you think students would benefit from being able to attend classes from home? Take a position on this issue. Support your response with reasons and examples.
essay_text:
While distance learning offers flexibility and convenience, I do not think it is as beneficial for students as attending classes in person. There are several reasons for this. 

Firstly, attending school in person allows for valuable social interaction and collaboration between students. At school, students can work together on group projects, have casual discussions to expand their understanding of lessons, and form important social and academic friendships. This kind of socialization and exchange of ideas is more difficult through an online environment. 

Secondly, it can be challenging for students to stay focused and stay on task when learning from home. There are many distractions at home like phones, television, chores, and even siblings or pets. It is easier for students' attention to wander without a teacher physically present instructing the class. This can negatively impact learning and understanding of lessons. 

Additionally, distance learning reduces opportunities for teachers to provide individualized attention and guidance to students who need extra support. With a class of students learning remotely, it is difficult for teachers to give one-on-one assistance, check individual comprehension, and identify learning difficulties of students. Immediate feedback and support is crucial for student success but harder to provide from a distance. 

While distance learning can be beneficial in some situations like illness, bad weather or for advanced students, I believe that for most students, especially younger ones, attending school in person is ideal for maximizing learning and growth. The social and academic benefits of a traditional classroom setting outweigh the flexibility afforded by distance options. For these key reasons, students are generally better served learning at school rather than from home via online classes.

essay_title: Write an explanatory essay to inform fellow citizens about the advantages of limiting car usage. Your essay must be based on ideas and information that can be found in the passage set. Manage your time carefully so that you can read the passages; plan your response; write your response; and revise and edit your response. Be sure to use evidence from multiple sources; and avoid overly relying on one source. Your response should be in the form of a multiparagraph essay. Write your essay in the space provided.
essay_text:
There are significant advantages to limiting car usage. Relying less on personal vehicles can benefit both individuals and communities in several important ways. 

Traffic congestion is a major problem in many urban areas. With more drivers on the roads each day, traffic jams are worsening. Fewer vehicles during peak hours would help reduce this congestion. Public transportation could help take cars off crowded streets and highways at these times. Buses and trains can move more people in less space compared to solo drivers. Limiting driving demand at popular commute times would ease traffic flow.

Reducing car dependence would also help address environmental issues. Automobiles are a primary source of air and noise pollution in cities. They emit greenhouse gases that contribute to climate change. By choosing alternatives like walking, cycling, or public transit when possible, individuals can lower their personal emissions impact. If a large portion of drivers shifted modes occasionally, it could tangibly improve urban air quality over time. Transitioning away from gas-powered vehicles en masse would support global efforts to limit global warming.

Not only would reducing car usage benefit the planet, it could also benefit personal health and finances. Cycling or walking to nearby destinations is a free form of exercise. Those who currently drive short distances could increase their daily activity levels at no cost. Lower mileage would also translate into savings on gas and car maintenance. Funds once spent on owning and operating a private vehicle could be reallocated to other priorities. Additionally, active travel helps reduce risks of chronic diseases associated with sedentary lifestyles like heart disease and diabetes.

In conclusion, limiting car usage through alternatives like public transportation, cycling, and walking can provide many advantages for communities and individuals. Less traffic congestion, improved air quality, greater public health, and cost savings are just some of the potential benefits of transitioning away from auto-dependency. Making wise transportation choices helps create a more sustainable environment and society overall.

essay_title:
Some of your friends perform community service. For example, some tutor elementary school children and others clean up litter. They think helping the community is very important. But other friends of yours think community service takes too much time away from what they need or want to do.
- Your principal is deciding whether to require all students to perform community service.
- Write a letter to your principal in which you take a position on whether students should be required to perform community service. Support your position with examples.
essay_text:
Dear Principal, 

I am writing regarding your consideration of requiring all students to perform community service. While helping the community is certainly a noble act, I do not think mandatory service is the best approach. There are better ways to encourage volunteerism without imposing requirements.

Requiring community service could undermine the spirit of volunteering. When service is mandatory, it is no longer volunteer work but an obligation. This may cause students to resent the work instead of finding value in helping others. True volunteering stems from personal motivation and care for one's community. Forcing students to volunteer takes away their autonomy to choose how to spend their free time.

Instead of making service mandatory, the school should actively promote opportunities for voluntary community involvement. Inform students about local nonprofit groups and civic projects where their contributions would be appreciated. Lead by example and organize school-wide drives to collect donations or perform acts of service as a united student body. Recognize students who volunteer their time through awards or honors to motivate others. 

For some students, extracurricular obligations like sports, clubs, religious activities or part-time jobs already consume much of their spare hours. Mandatory community service risks overburdening these time-committed students. It could negatively impact their academic performance or cause them to drop valued activities. The school should be understanding of students' varying responsibilities and schedules.

In closing, while the intent of requiring community service is admirable, a mandatory policy is not the most effective approach. Positive encouragement of volunteering through promotion and recognition will inspire more students to support important causes without imposing obligations on their free time. I hope the school considers alternative methods to community service that maintain its spirit of volunteerism.

essay_title: You have just read the article, 'A Cowboy Who Rode the Waves.' Luke's participation in the Seagoing Cowboys program allowed him to experience adventures and visit many unique places. Using information from the article, write an argument from Luke's point of view convincing others to participate in the Seagoing Cowboys program. Be sure to include: reasons to join the program; details from the article to support Luke's claims; an introduction, a body, and a conclusion to your essay.
essay_text:
My Seagoing Adventures 

Growing up on a ranch in rural Kansas, I always dreamed of seeing what lay beyond the wide open plains. When I learned about the Seagoing Cowboys program from a friend, I saw it as my chance to escape everyday life and embark on an exciting journey. This program allowed me to experience more than I ever imagined and I would encourage anyone with a spirit of adventure to join us on the high seas.

Being out on the water for months at a time presented amazing opportunities to visit new places and meet all sorts of people, from fishermen in Dutch Harbor to scientists in the Bering Sea. The article detailed my travels to Alaska, where I helped with research projects amid stunning landscapes covered in snow and ice. I even got to interact with seals and seabirds up close during our stops at remote islands. These unforgettable encounters with nature and cultures very different than my own back home truly opened my eyes to the vast diversity of our world. 

In addition to experiencing new destinations, participating in the program also allowed me to learn important skills. On the boats, I assisted with tasks like sailing, navigation, and maintenance that have proven useful in my daily life. Facing challenges like twenty-foot waves in the Bering Sea taught me all about perseverance and teamwork. I gained self-assurance from knowing that I could adapt to unpredictable conditions far from familiar shores. Overall, the hands-on activities through Seagoing Cowboys helped me grow in capability and confidence in myself.

My time with the program was short but left me with lifelong memories and confidence to take on future challenges. I believe that any adventurous spirit could greatly benefit from the opportunities the Seagoing Cowboys provides to see this wonderful planet up close and become a more well-rounded, experienced person. I know joining them opened my eyes to the possibilities outside my small town life and helped set me on a path I never could have imagined. For seeking adventure on the open water and a chance to discover your hidden strengths, I recommend applying for this once-in-a-lifetime experience.

essay_title: Some schools offer distance learning as an option for students to attend classes from home by way of online or video conferencing. Do you think students would benefit from being able to attend classes from home? Take a position on this issue. Support your response with reasons and examples.
essay_text:
While distance learning offers flexibility and convenience, I believe students would benefit more from attending traditional in-person classes. There are a few key reasons for this.

First, learning from home could negatively impact students' social development and mental well-being. Part of the school experience is socializing and interacting with peers. At home, students may feel isolated without in-person interactions during breaks and after school. The social aspects of school are important for developing social skills and helping to prevent loneliness or depression. 

Second, it can be difficult for students to stay focused and motivated while learning from home. There are many distractions at home like TV, phones, video games and chores that may tempt students. It requires strong self-discipline to avoid distractions and stick to an at-home schedule. Younger students especially may struggle without the structured environment of a classroom.

Third, online classes lack the hands-on learning experiences that in-person classes provide. Some subjects like lab sciences, arts, sports and trades benefit greatly from practical demonstrations and activities that simply cannot be replicated remotely. The experiential nature of these classes enhances understanding and retention of the material. It also allows students to get help from and ask questions to their teachers in real-time.

While distance learning offers flexibility, I believe the social and educational benefits of traditional in-person classes outweigh this convenience. Students' well-being and development are best supported through direct engagement and teaching within a structured school environment. Therefore, attending physical classes at school would be more beneficial for students than distance learning from home.

essay_title: When people ask for advice, they sometimes talk to more than one person. Explain why seeking multiple opinions can help someone make a better choice. Use specific details and examples in your response.
essay_text:
Seeking multiple opinions when asking for advice can help someone make a better choice for a few key reasons. First, getting different perspectives allows you to consider more alternatives and options that you may not have thought of on your own. Each person you ask is likely to have had different experiences that could potentially provide new ideas or approaches. 

Secondly, discussing your dilemma with more than one person acts as a check against any biases a single advisor might have. No one individual can ever provide a perfectly objective view - we all have our own preferences, prejudices or blind spots. However, balancing various viewpoints helps mitigate those influences by bringing more overall neutrality. You're less likely to be swayed in one direction if different advisors point out both pros and cons instead of just focusing on what favors their own preferences.

A third benefit is that more counsel means more chances of getting well-rounded, thoughtful advice. Any individual you speak to may not consider all angles or implications of the choices comprehensively. But together, multiple advisors can point you toward factors you hadn't accounted for and play "devil's advocate" by countering arguments you'd made to yourself. No one person can anticipate and address every possible concern or objection, so combining insights broadens the advice. 

In conclusion, while any one advisor could potentially provide helpful guidance, seeking input from a variety of trusted sources allows you to view your situation from more standpoints. This balanced approach can better equip you to weigh your options and ultimately make the choice that seems most reasonable after seriously evaluating alternatives from many perspectives. Getting multiple opinions helps ensure a decision is well-informed instead of potentially missing important things a single recommendation alone might overlook.

essay_title: In the article “Driverless Cars are Coming,” the author presents both positive and negative aspects of driverless cars. Using details from the article, create an argument for or against the development of these cars. Be sure to include: your position on driverless cars; appropriate details from the article that support your position; an introduction, a body, and a conclusion to your argumentative essay.
essay_text:
While driverless cars pose both opportunities and risks, on balance their development will significantly benefit society. 

As the article notes, these vehicles could reduce traffic accidents which are often caused by human error such as distracted driving or drunkenness. Automated cars communicate with each other and brake or steer to avoid collisions, meaning they could eliminate over 90% of crashes according to some estimates. This would save thousands of lives each year in the US alone. 

Driverless cars may also increase access to transportation. They could help the elderly or disabled who cannot currently drive to more easily access medical care, shopping, and social activities. Autonomous taxis and buses may expand public transit options for those in areas without good existing service. This could combat isolation and support quality of life.

Progress does need responsible oversight to manage risks. Developers must extensively test automated systems to address all foreseen situations accurately and avoid any deaths from software or hardware failures. Laws and guidelines must also balance innovation with safety concerns from the public. With careful planning and open communication from companies, regulators could approve life-saving technologies while reassuring the wary.  

Overall the societal good of driverless cars outweighs potential issues given reasonable policy. While change brings uncertainty, this technology could transform mobility for the better if introduced prudently. Lives would be spared daily traffic accidents. More people would gain independence. With diligence during development and operation, autonomous vehicles can and should become part of building a transportation system that moves people safely.

essay_title: In the article “Driverless Cars are Coming,” the author presents both positive and negative aspects of driverless cars. Using details from the article, create an argument for or against the development of these cars. Be sure to include: your position on driverless cars; appropriate details from the article that support your position; an introduction, a body, and a conclusion to your argumentative essay.
essay_text:
The Development of Driverless Cars

While the rise of driverless cars presents many promising benefits, there are also significant risks that must be addressed before embracing their widespread adoption. According to the article "Driverless Cars are Coming", autonomous vehicles could help reduce traffic accidents caused by human error, provide mobility for those unable to drive themselves, and ease traffic congestion through improved routing. However, the technology also faces challenges that could compromise safety and public acceptance if not adequately addressed beforehand. 

One of the major advantages of driverless cars discussed is their potential to reduce accidents. As the article notes, over 90% of crashes are currently caused by human error in judgment or operation of a vehicle. By removing the human element, autonomous driving systems aim to make road travel much safer through their ability to sense surroundings, obey traffic laws, and react more quickly than people in risky situations. At the same time though, the technology still has limitations since it has yet to encounter every possible scenario on the road. Unforeseen issues could potentially emerge as the systems face real-world conditions, demonstrating the need for extensive testing and monitoring during initial deployment to identify flaws.

In addition, losing the human control element may concern some who feel uneasy abandoning direct control of their movement. As the article points out, public fear over risks like hacking and software or sensor failures could undermine acceptance of the technology. Automakers will need to invest heavily in cybersecurity and address privacy and liability concerns to alleviate such worries. Comprehensive user education on autonomous capabilities and limitations can also help reassure those anxious over losing the driver's seat. 

In conclusion, while driverless cars hold promise for major safety and mobility improvements, fully realizing their benefits will require technical challenges to be solved and public trust to be earned. A phased rollout closely watched by regulators appears the most prudent path forward to allow problems to be addressed methodically before widespread autonomous driving becomes the norm. With sufficient testing, oversight and transparent communication of progress, this innovative technology could ultimately transform transportation for the better once trust in its safety and security is established.

essay_title: You have read the article 'Unmasking the Face on Mars.' Imagine you are a scientist at NASA discussing the Face with someone who thinks it was created by aliens. Using information in the article, write an argumentative essay to convince someone that the Face is just a natural landform.Be sure to include: claims to support your argument that the Face is a natural landform; evidence from the article to support your claims; an introduction, a body, and a conclusion to your argumentative essay.
essay_text:
While some have speculated that the "Face on Mars" was created by aliens, the evidence strongly suggests that it is merely a natural landform formed by geological processes. In the article "Unmasking the Face on Mars," several key points are made that support the idea that the Face is of natural origin. 

One of the main claims is that the Face lacks distinctive artificial features that one would expect to see if it were actually created by an intelligent entity. Upon closer examination with improved imaging technology onboard spacecraft like MGS, the Face appears amorphous and lacks well-defined structures like eyes, a nose, or mouth. If aliens intended to leave a distinct calling card, it seems strange that they would create an image so poorly defined that it barely resembles a face at all. 

Additionally, the article notes that the surrounding geological context provides clues that the Face is a result of natural erosion. The terrain it is situated within has been heavily sculpted by wind and contains many other rolling mesa-like formations of similarly ambiguous shapes. Being located in an area heavily shaped by natural wind and weather patterns makes it highly plausible that the Face is yet another oddly-formed mesa rather than artificially constructed monument. 

Perhaps the strongest evidence that it is a natural landform comes from data showing that the Face's appearance changes substantially with even minor alterations in the angle of illumination and shadows. Its features are enhanced or erased depending on the position of the sun, demonstrating that it has no intrinsic defined structure and is simply an optical illusion resulting from shadows falling across naturally-eroded slopes and mesas. If aliens had gone through the trouble of constructing an image, it seems unlikely they would have made it so fragile and dependent on precise lighting conditions to even be perceived.

In conclusion, while the "Face on Mars" may spark imaginations of alien visitations to the red planet, the preponderance of evidence from improved images and geological context analysis supports the conclusion that it is a mundane natural landform rather than an artificial construct. Its poorly defined appearance, form mirroring surrounding terrain, and mutable features under differing illumination all point to a prosaic origin from natural geological forms rather than alien intervention. Unless more compelling evidence surfaces, the "Face on Mars" is best regarded as merely an optical illusion rather than proof of intelligent design or visitation.

essay_title: You have just read the article, 'A Cowboy Who Rode the Waves.' Luke's participation in the Seagoing Cowboys program allowed him to experience adventures and visit many unique places. Using information from the article, write an argument from Luke's point of view convincing others to participate in the Seagoing Cowboys program. Be sure to include: reasons to join the program; details from the article to support Luke's claims; an introduction, a body, and a conclusion to your essay.
essay_text:
Participating in Adventure

As a lifelong cowboy, when I first heard about the Seagoing Cowboys program, I was immediately intrigued by the opportunity to take my skills riding waves instead of horses. While cattle drives across open ranges used to fuel my sense of adventure, modern ranch life no longer satisfied my restless spirit. The Seagoing Cowboys offered me a chance to experience the unpredictability and thrill of the ocean while learning new skills. I knew this program was for me. 

There are countless reasons others should join just as I did. First and foremost, it allows cowboys to engage in adventure once more. As the article discussed, each day brought surprises as I helped with tasks like fixing sails or spotting wildlife. Never knowing what challenges or delights tomorrow would bring kept me constantly on my toes. Second, it opened my eyes to new places and cultures. The article detailed my travels to unique ports around the world, from the Caribbean to Scandinavia. Experiencing diverse ways of life far from my Texas ranch broadened my horizons. 

Additionally, mastering an entirely new domain builds confidence. Riding waves is no easy feat, but with patience and guidance from the captain, I gained proficiency in ocean navigation, boat handling, and seamanship. Meeting such a steep learning curve with success reinforced that I could achieve any goal through determination. That kind of personal growth is priceless. 

In closing, if you crave adventure, yearn to see the planet, and want to push your boundaries, I encourage joining the Seagoing Cowboys. As the article shows, it brought me experiences I'll treasure forever. I guarantee theProgram will fuel your spirit just as it did mine. Don't let convenient ranch work prevent (convince?) you from living your freest, boldest life. Cast off and discover your capabilities. I promise the rewards are well worth any risks.

essay_title:
Your principal is reconsidering the school's cell phone policy. She is considering two possible policies:
- Policy 1: Allow students to bring phones to school and use them during lunch periods and other free times, as long as the phones are turned off during class time.
- Policy 2: Do not allow students to have phones at school at all.
Write a letter to your principal convincing her which policy you believe is better. Support your position with specific reasons.
essay_text:
Dear Principal, 

I am writing to provide my perspective on the school's cell phone policy options under consideration. Of the two possibilities, I believe Policy 1 is the better choice as it allows a reasonable use of technology while still supporting an effective learning environment.

Policy 1 respects that cell phones are now an integral part of students' lives outside of school. For many students, keeping in touch with family and friends during free periods is important. By permitting phones during lunch and breaks as long as they are off in class, this policy accommodates modern communication needs while also enforcing focus on schoolwork when lessons are taking place. A strict ban under Policy 2 is unrealistic given how intertwined phones are with daily life now. 

Additionally, allowing controlled phone use per Policy 1 can help students feel more trusted and responsible. If given guidelines rather than prohibitions, students are more likely to properly follow the rules. By contrast, an outright ban may cause unintentional rebellion or disobedience. Treating high schoolers with appropriate freedom balanced with structure fosters maturity and citizenship.   

Of course, limiting cell phone distraction during academic time remains key. Policy 1 directly addresses this concern by requiring phones be off in class. This balanced approach supports learning while still acknowledging communication needs. An absolute prohibition seems excessive and could damage student-administrator relations.

In conclusion, I believe Policy 1 offers the wisest path forward. It empowers students through reasonable trust but also maintains focus on school priorities when most important. Overall learning, well-being and school culture are best served through this balanced, pragmatic option. Thank you for considering my perspective on this important topic.

essay_title: You have just read the article, 'A Cowboy Who Rode the Waves.' Luke's participation in the Seagoing Cowboys program allowed him to experience adventures and visit many unique places. Using information from the article, write an argument from Luke's point of view convincing others to participate in the Seagoing Cowboys program. Be sure to include: reasons to join the program; details from the article to support Luke's claims; an introduction, a body, and a conclusion to your essay.
essay_text:
Joining the Adventure of a Lifetime 

When I first joined the Seagoing Cowboys program, I had no idea what an incredible experience it would be. Growing up on a cattle ranch in Colorado, my life revolved around outdoor work and caring for livestock. While rewarding, it could also get repetitive day to day. That all changed when I learned about the opportunity to spend months at sea, herding cattle on cargo ships traveling worldwide. This was a once in a lifetime chance to not only see new places, but live an adventure I'll never forget. I want to share why anyone interested in travel, animals, or seeking excitement should strongly consider applying for this program. 

The article described my awe at all the beautiful destinations I got to visit while on assignments. As a cowboy responsible for cattle welfare during ocean voyages, my work took me to ports across Europe and Asia. I've ridden waves to France, gazed at skyscrapers in Hong Kong, and taken in ancient architecture in Greece - all while continuing my vocation. Most people will never have a chance to experience so many cultures firsthand. Being based at sea also meant daily sunrises and sunsets unlike anything seen at home in Colorado. For anyone wanting to witness spectacular sunrises and natural scenery daily, this program delivers.

Another huge benefit outlined was learning invaluable skills. On the open ocean, each day brings unexpected circumstances that test even experienced cowboys. By gaining practical boating knowledge and having autonomy over livestock in unfamiliar territory, I grew tremendously confident in my abilities. The financial compensation also allowed traveling costs to be covered while gaining work experience internationally. For adventurous souls seeking personal growth or career building outside typical schedules, the Seagoing Cowboys program empowers long term professional development like nothing else.  

In summary, the article captures why I'm still glad I took a chance on this once in a lifetime offer. For anyone passionate about animals, travel, or living fully outside their comfort zone, I encourage seriously considering applying. The program gives cowboys an experience of global proportions, teaching lessons that can't be learned anywhere else. I guarantee joining would lead to memories, skills, and stories to last a lifetime.

essay_title: You have read the article 'Unmasking the Face on Mars.' Imagine you are a scientist at NASA discussing the Face with someone who thinks it was created by aliens. Using information in the article, write an argumentative essay to convince someone that the Face is just a natural landform.Be sure to include: claims to support your argument that the Face is a natural landform; evidence from the article to support your claims; an introduction, a body, and a conclusion to your argumentative essay.
essay_text:
While the idea of ancient aliens visiting Mars is exciting to contemplate, the evidence tells us that the "Face on Mars" is simply a result of natural geological formations and processes. The phenomenon can be fully explained without invoking extraterrestrial intervention. 

Some key claims my essay would make are that wind erosion over eons sculpted the Martian terrain into interesting shapes that resemble familiar objects to our eyes. The article details how images from newer satellites with higher resolution show the "Face" is an unlikely shape for an artificial construct. Its dimensions and features match those caused by natural weathering much more closely. 

To support these assertions, I would cite specifics from the article. For example, it notes images from the Mars Global Surveyor revealed the Face's height varied unevenly in a way inconsistent with design by intelligent beings. Canyons and mesas in the surrounding area display similar forms and textures caused strictly by wind blowing dust and rock particles. The scale and symmetrical patterns are what our brains are wired to recognize as faces due to evolution, even if they were formed randomly.   

In conclusion, while the mind sees what it wants in interpreting visual patterns, science requires following evidence where it leads rather than preferring fanciful explanations. In this case, comparisons to undisputedly natural landforms nearby and insights from improved imaging definitively prove the "Face on Mars" is a quirk of nature rather than proof of visiting aliens. Though more prosaic than that hypothesis, facts show the landscape features arose from normal Martian geological activity alone over billions of years. An anthropic interpretation, however tempting, does not hold up under scrutiny here. Nature sculpted a suggestive-looking shape through exposure to wind and dust, not extraterrestrials shaping a meaningful message for us to find.

essay_title: In the article "Making Mona Lisa Smile," the author describes how a new technology called the Facial Action Coding System enables computers to identify human emotions. Using details from the article, write an essay arguing whether the use of this technology to read the emotional expressions of students in a classroom is valuable.
essay_text:
