In the process of planning their own work, students must set goals, manage their time efficiently, and find educational resources – valuable “soft” skills that serve them well beyond the summer months. Having ownership over their learning also helps instill a sense of responsibility. 

In summary, while both teacher and student input have roles to play, student-designed summer work generally leads to deeper engagement with material that sticks better with the individual. Within reason, focusing on student interests and initiative, rather than mandates, makes summer learning more meaningful and impactful for the upcoming school year.

essay_title: You have just read the article, 'A Cowboy Who Rode the Waves.' Luke's participation in the Seagoing Cowboys program allowed him to experience adventures and visit many unique places. Using information from the article, write an argument from Luke's point of view convincing others to participate in the Seagoing Cowboys program. Be sure to include: reasons to join the program; details from the article to support Luke's claims; an introduction, a body, and a conclusion to your essay.
essay_text:
The Open Seas Await

For years I lived and worked on my family's ranch in southern Texas, tending to our cattle day in and day out. While I loved being outdoors and the sense of purpose my work provided, I often found myself dreaming of what adventures might lie beyond the horizon. Then I came across an article about a unique program called Seagoing Cowboys, which gave ranch hands the chance to spend time aboard tall ships, experiencing life at sea while helping crew vessels around the world. I knew immediately this was just the opportunity I had been waiting for. 

This program offered experiences I never could have imagined on the ranch. As the article detailed, I would get to set sail on historic sail training ships to international ports, gaining exposure to diverse cultures along the way. No longer would my surroundings be defined by barbed wire fences and grazing cattle. Instead, the open ocean would be my office, with constantly changing seascapes as far as the eye could see. I also looked forward to learning new skills, like navigating by the stars and operating the sails without motors. These would be valuable lessons that would stay with me for life, far beyond the duration of the program.

Perhaps most importantly, participating in Seagoing Cowboys opened my eyes to just how small my world had been up to that point. As the article noted, I was able to witness endangered species like humpback whales in their natural habitat. I met people from all over the world and heard their stories, gaining a new appreciation for other cultures and ways of life. The program truly broadened my horizons in a way a desk job never could have. Now, whenever I feel like my work is becoming routine, I think back to my voyages with Seagoing Cowboys and am instantly re-energized and eager to take on new challenges. 

It is clear to me this program is an unparalleled opportunity for personal and professional growth. For anyone seeking adventure beyond their daily routines and a chance to gain global perspectives, I wholeheartedly recommend Seagoing Cowboys. The open seas await - don't hesitate to answer their call. A world of discovery is just beginning for those who do.

essay_title: In the article "Making Mona Lisa Smile," the author describes how a new technology called the Facial Action Coding System enables computers to identify human emotions. Using details from the article, write an essay arguing whether the use of this technology to read the emotional expressions of students in a classroom is valuable.
essay_text: While the Facial Action Coding System technology has promise to provide insights into students' emotions, its use to read students' expressions in the classroom could pose problems if not carefully implemented. On one hand, identifying when students are experiencing confusion, boredom or other negative emotions could help teachers tailor their lessons more effectively to enhance learning and engagement. This technology might allow teachers to make quicker adjustments when certain concepts are not being grasped or when the class seems disengaged. However, there are also risks to consider. Continually monitoring students' facial expressions could create an uncomfortable or invasive environment if not done discreetly and with consent. Students may feel like they are being constantly watched and judged. Important non-verbal cues between students may be impeded. There are also questions around data privacy and how information about students' emotions would be stored, shared, and potentially used. Before using this technology in the classroom, policies would need to be developed to ensure student privacy and obtain permission from parents and students. Clear communication would also be required about how the data is intended to help students, not judge them. With careful consideration of these issues and students' well-being, this technology could provide insights to teachers to help improve the learning experience. But unchecked use risks worsening student anxiety and compromising their privacy. Overall, more research and stringent guidelines are needed to help determine if and how this technology's benefits could outweigh its drawbacks in a classroom setting.

essay_title: In the article "Making Mona Lisa Smile," the author describes how a new technology called the Facial Action Coding System enables computers to identify human emotions. Using details from the article, write an essay arguing whether the use of this technology to read the emotional expressions of students in a classroom is valuable.
essay_text:
While technology to identify human emotions holds promise, using facial recognition in classrooms raises concerns. On one hand, it could help teachers understand students' engagement and adjust lessons accordingly. However, student privacy and autonomy are also important. 

Facial expression is a private, subconscious act, and constant monitoring could inhibit natural expression. It may also lead to misinterpretations without nuanced context about each student. Well-meaning attempts to address disengagement could backfire if students feel surveilled or that their emotional experiences are being oversimplified. 

A more constructive approach may be occasional, opt-in emotion checks by the system to provide teachers qualitative feedback for self-reflection. But discretion is key - fine-tuning instruction is reasonable, while abnormal emotional logging or punitive measures based solely on facial scans would undermine the student-teacher relationship. 

Overall, the technology exhibits potential to enhance education if respecting student agency and privacy remain paramount. Consent, anonymization of data, and limiting scans to discrete evaluations — not constant surveillance — could help ensure it empowerswithout infringing on rights or reducing complex human experiences to simplistic readings of facial muscles. With care and moderation, emotional analysis holds promise. But giventhe sensitivity of classrooms, open communication and voluntary participationshould take priority over jump to constant, coercive monitoring.

essay_title:
Your principal is reconsidering the school's cell phone policy. She is considering two possible policies:
- Policy 1: Allow students to bring phones to school and use them during lunch periods and other free times, as long as the phones are turned off during class time.
- Policy 2: Do not allow students to have phones at school at all.
Write a letter to your principal convincing her which policy you believe is better. Support your position with specific reasons.
essay_text:
Dear Principal Smith, 

I am writing to express my opinion on the school's cell phone policy options under consideration. After reviewing both Policy 1 and Policy 2, I believe that Policy 1 is the better choice as it allows limited, responsible cell phone use while still maintaining an appropriate learning environment.

Policy 1 would grant students more freedom by permitting phones to be brought to school and used during lunch and free periods. For many students, having their phones provides a sense of security and means of communication with families if needed. Restricting use only to non-academic times ensures phones do not disrupt learning in the classroom. Students would still be able to benefit from modern connectivity and stay in touch with friends and activities outside of school, which supports mental wellness.  

At the same time, Policy 1 upholds the school's core function by requiring phones to be turned off during class. This prevents any possible distractions that could compromise academic focus and performance. Teachers would be able to conduct lessons without disruptions from phones ringing or buzzing. The policy also maintains structure and supervision of cell phone activities within reasonable bounds.

In contrast, Policy 2 banning phones altogether may go too far and potentially backfire. It risks resentment from students who see phones as an important part of daily life. A total ban could foster more rule-breaking as students try to sneak phone usage. The policy also does not consider legitimate reasons why some students need their phones for safety or communication with parents regarding rides and activities.  

In conclusion, Policy 1 is the wisest approach as it grants students appropriate privileges while still prioritizing learning as the main priority during school hours. This balanced option respects students' needs and responsibilities. I believe most students would appreciate and follow its reasonable guidelines. Thank you for your consideration of my views on this important issue impacting our school community. Please let me know if you need any clarification or have additional questions.

essay_title: Your principal has decided that all students must participate in at least one extracurricular activity. For example, students could participate in sports, work on the yearbook, or serve on the student council. Do you agree or disagree with this decision? Use specific details and examples to convince others to support your position.
essay_text:
I disagree with the principal's decision that all students must participate in at least one extracurricular activity. While extracurricular activities can provide many benefits, forcing participation does not respect student choices and priorities. 

Some students have responsibilities outside of school that should come first. They may need to care for family members after school or work part-time jobs to help support their families. Mandating extracurricular activities would create undue stress on these students and potentially prevent them from fulfilling important obligations. School's main priority should be academic learning, not mandatory extracurricular involvement.

Not all activities suit every student's interests and strengths. A one-size-fits-all approach does not recognize that students have diverse talents, passions and goals. Some thrive in sports, others in arts or academics. Forcing involvement could demotivate students from finding their own paths. It's better to offer a variety of options and let individual interests and time commitments determine involvement. 

Extracurricular activities are most valuable and meaningful when students choose to participate voluntarily based on their own motivations. Forced participation may result in half-hearted involvement just to fulfill the requirement. It also takes away student agency and self-directed learning. The life lessons gained from extracurriculars like time management, leadership and teamwork are best realized when students opt into activities of their own free will.

In conclusion, while extracurricular activities provide benefits, mandating participation against some students' wishes is an overreach. Schools should respect students' varied lives and priorities outside the classroom. Offering diverse options for voluntary involvement respects student choice and allows them to shape meaningful experiences outside of academics on their own terms.

essay_title: Some schools offer distance learning as an option for students to attend classes from home by way of online or video conferencing. Do you think students would benefit from being able to attend classes from home? Take a position on this issue. Support your response with reasons and examples.
essay_text:
While distance learning offers flexibility, I believe that attending classes in person provides greater benefits to students. There are several reasons why face-to-face classes are preferable to remote learning from home.

Firstly, being physically present at school allows for more focused learning. At home, students may face distractions from siblings, chores, or technology that reduce their ability to concentrate fully on their schoolwork. In a traditional classroom setting, teachers can more easily maintain an environment conducive to learning without outside influences. 

Secondly, learning from home can leave students feeling isolated from their peers. Part of the educational experience is collaborating with and learning from other students. Direct social interaction at school fosters relationship-building skills and teamwork. It also gives students opportunities for discussions and questions that may be more difficult remotely. 

Finally, attending classes in-person gives students experience that prepares them for their future. Most careers will require showing up somewhere other than home each day and interacting face-to-face with colleagues. Being present at a school helps develop important time-management, social, and professional skills. It also provides equitable access to extracurricular activities like sports teams that support well-rounded development.

While distance learning has its place, especially in unique circumstances, I believe the social and career-preparatory advantages of face-to-face school outweigh those of remote schooling from home as a long-term learning model. For most students, being physically present at their school of enrollment leads to better educational outcomes and a more well-rounded high school experience. That is why attending classes in-person remains preferable to distance learning as the standard option.

essay_title: In the article "Making Mona Lisa Smile," the author describes how a new technology called the Facial Action Coding System enables computers to identify human emotions. Using details from the article, write an essay arguing whether the use of this technology to read the emotional expressions of students in a classroom is valuable.
essay_text:
The potential use of facial recognition technology like the Facial Action Coding System to read student emotions in the classroom warrants a balanced discussion. On one hand, such technology could provide teachers valuable insight into how their lessons are landing with students and whether anyone may need extra support. Knowing if students seem bored, confused or frustrated could help teachers adapt their approach to maximize learning. This technology may also help identify students struggling with conditions like depression or anxiety, allowing teachers to intervene earlier. 

However, there are also legitimate privacy and implementation concerns. Continuous monitoring of student facial expressions could feel intrusive and inhibit natural emotional responses. Facial recognition technology is also still developing and not perfectly accurate, risking misinterpretations. Teachers may come to rely too much on the technology rather than their own observations of students. There are also questions around how the collected emotional data would be stored, shared, and potentially used over time.

Overall, using facial recognition to read student emotions in the classroom presents an interesting opportunity but alsorisks that would need careful consideration. If implemented properly with student and parent consent, input from educators, and strong privacy safeguards, it could provide helpful insights. But unfettered or inaccurate use could undermine the learning environment and student well-being. More research is likely needed to determine if the benefits truly outweigh the challenges in practice. A pilot program with oversight and willingness to refine the approach seems a reasonable first step to further explore the potential valueof this developing technology in classrooms.

essay_title: In the article “Driverless Cars are Coming,” the author presents both positive and negative aspects of driverless cars. Using details from the article, create an argument for or against the development of these cars. Be sure to include: your position on driverless cars; appropriate details from the article that support your position; an introduction, a body, and a conclusion to your argumentative essay.
essay_text:
The Development of Driverless Cars

While driverless cars offer convenience and safety benefits, their widespread adoption also poses risks that require careful consideration. According to the article, autonomous vehicles could reduce traffic accidents by up to 90% since most crashes today are caused by human error. Without drivers to become distracted, tired, or impaired, these cars aim to navigate roads safely using sensors and software. However, the technology is still untested at scale, and hackers represent a danger if they manage to interfere with vehicle systems. 

More testing is needed to validate the software's ability to handle unexpected situations appropriately. The article questions whether autonomous cars can identify uncertain scenarios as well as human drivers. While sensors may detect obstacles, interpreting unusual conditions still poses a challenge. Before driverless cars dominate roads, their decision-making protocols must prove reliable even when encountering situations unlike what programmers anticipated. Lives depend on the technology performing flawlessly.

Public distrust could also delay widespread acceptance. Many people may feel uneasy relying on artificial intelligence instead of personal control for transportation. Hackers targeting autonomous systems increase anxieties about digital security and privacy. Gaining trust requires automakers and tech firms to prioritize safety and shield vehicles from cyber threats through engineering practices and legally enforced protocols. 

In conclusion, while driverless cars offer safety advantages over humans when functioning properly, uncertainties remain regarding emerging technologies and public perception. Before self-driving vehicles become standard, developers must assuage concerns about how the software handles intricate dilemmas and prove resilience against hacking through rigorous testing and regulations. With a careful, evidence-based approach that prioritizes security over speed to market, autonomous transportation could ultimately prevent many car accidents if implemented responsibly.

essay_title: In "The Challenge of Exploring Venus," the author suggests studying Venus is a worthy pursuit despite the dangers it presents. Using details from the article, write an essay evaluating how well the author supports this idea. Be sure to include: a claim that evaluates how well the author supports the idea that studying Venus is a worthy pursuit despite the dangers; an explanation of the evidence from the article that supports your claim; an introduction, a body, and a conclusion to your essay.
essay_text:
Studying Venus Remains a Worthy Pursuit

The article "The Challenge of Exploring Venus" makes a persuasive case that studying Venus is worthwhile despite the planet's hazardous conditions. The author outlines several compelling reasons why learning about Earth's closest planetary neighbor merits continued exploration efforts, in spite of the dangers involved. 

One key piece of evidence presented is that Venus offers scientists an opportunity to study how greenhouse gases drastically alter a planet's climate. With surface temperatures hot enough to melt lead and an atmosphere made almost entirely of carbon dioxide, Venus represents an extreme case of the greenhouse effect. Exploring Venus could help reveal the mechanics of runaway global warming, improving our understanding of climate change here on Earth. The article notes this scientific reward justifies enduring the planet's formidable atmosphere.

The author also argues that Venus may preserve geological clues about the early evolution of our solar system. As one of the inner planets closer to the Sun, Venus likely solidified from a magma ocean much like Earth. Discovering more about Venus's geological history could illuminate that of Earth and other rocky worlds. The article cites evidence from past missions that Venus may still have active volcanoes, making it crucial to follow up on those initial findings. 

While traversing Venus's inhospitable environment presents immense hurdles, the author makes a strong case that the scientific dividends of studying our sister planet are highly valuable. By illuminating climate change processes and offering a window into the development of terrestrial planets, Venus has much to teach us despite the risks involved in exploring it. For these compelling reasons, overcoming the difficulties to learn more about Venus remains a worthwhile scientific endeavor. The author presents a thoughtful evaluation of why probing this harsh yet enlightening world merits ongoing dedicated efforts.

essay_title: In the article "Making Mona Lisa Smile," the author describes how a new technology called the Facial Action Coding System enables computers to identify human emotions. Using details from the article, write an essay arguing whether the use of this technology to read the emotional expressions of students in a classroom is valuable.
essay_text: The use of Facial Action Coding System (FACS) technology to read students' emotional expressions in the classroom is valuable but should be implemented carefully. On one hand, this technology could help teachers gain insights into how students are feeling about their lessons. If a class appears disengaged or frustrated, teachers could adjust their teaching approach to better connect with students. Identifying specific students who are struggling with understanding or experiencing other issues would allow teachers to provide additional support as needed. However, this technology also raises valid privacy and ethical concerns. Continually monitoring students' facial expressions without their consent could undermine their sense of privacy and autonomy at school. It may also lead to misinterpreting a student's emotional state or make them feel self-conscious about expressing themselves naturally. Therefore, if used, guidelines would need to be established around only occasional and selective use of this technology with student consent. Opt-in programs that allow families to choose whether their children participate could balance these considerations. With proper safeguards and oversight on its application in the classroom, FACS technology shows potential to improve education by giving teachers a helpful tool for student insight and support. But its use also warrants careful discussion due to legitimate concerns around student privacy, autonomy and well-being. Overall, a limited and sensible implementation of this technology could provide value if executed responsibly and with student consent.

essay_title: Some schools require students to complete summer projects to assure they continue learning during their break. Should these summer projects be teacher-designed or student-designed? Take a position on this question. Support your response with reasons and specific examples.
essay_text:
Schools should allow for more student-designed summer projects rather than having all projects teacher-designed. Giving students some autonomy over their summer work can help engage them more in their own learning. While teacher-designed projects ensure students cover certain topics, student-designed projects allow for more flexibility and choice. This can motivate students and help them learn in a way that interests them. 

If students have the opportunity to choose their own summer project topics, they are more likely to pick something they genuinely want to learn more about. Students will be intrinsically motivated to dedicate time and effort when they feel ownership over their work. For example, a student interested in sports may choose to research different training techniques for their favorite team. Another student passionate about music could decide to learn how to play a new instrument. When students follow their own interests, they are motivated to explore a subject in depth.

However, it's also important that teachers provide guidance to students as they design their own projects. Teachers should approve project topics to ensure they meet educational standards and are appropriately challenging. Teachers could also suggest sample project options if a student needs ideas or is undecided. With teacher support and parameters in place, students can benefit from the independence of a self-designed project while still covering required curricular areas. 

A combination of teacher-designed mandatory projects, mixed with opportunities for student-designed optional enrichment projects, would be ideal. This balances ensuring students learn what teachers feel is most important, with allowing student voice and choice in their learning too. Overall, involving students more directly in designing their own summer work can deepen engagement with learning outside the classroom.

essay_title:
Your principal is reconsidering the school's cell phone policy. She is considering two possible policies:
- Policy 1: Allow students to bring phones to school and use them during lunch periods and other free times, as long as the phones are turned off during class time.
- Policy 2: Do not allow students to have phones at school at all.
Write a letter to your principal convincing her which policy you believe is better. Support your position with specific reasons.
essay_text:
Dear Principal Smith, 

I am writing to you regarding the cell phone policy options you are considering for our school. After thinking carefully about Policy 1 and Policy 2, I believe that Policy 1 is the better choice. Allowing students to bring phones to school but requiring them to be turned off during class time strikes the right balance.

If phones are completely banned as in Policy 2, it may cause more issues than it solves. Students will still try to sneak phones into the school against the rules, which could lead to discipline problems. Additionally, many students rely on their phones after school for important communication with parents about rides home or extracurricular activities. A total ban would prevent this.

Policy 1 addresses teachers' concerns about phones being a distraction during lessons by requiring them to be off during class time. However, it still gives students access to phones during free periods like lunch. Many students like to check social media, listen to music, or text friends during these breaks. Denying them phones entirely seems unnecessary.

Policy 1 teaches students responsibility by allowing phones if used properly while still in school. They must show they can follow the rules of turning phones off during lessons. This trusting approach to policy encourages maturity from students. 

In conclusion, I believe Policy 1 strikes the best balance of allowing legitimate phone use while also respecting classroom learning time. It promotes responsibility from students through a sensible, trusting policy. For these reasons, I ask you to choose Policy 1 as the new cell phone policy for our school.

Thank you for your consideration.

Sincerely,
[Your name]

essay_title: Some schools require students to complete summer projects to assure they continue learning during their break. Should these summer projects be teacher-designed or student-designed? Take a position on this question. Support your response with reasons and specific examples.
essay_text:
While summer is meant to be a break from the usual school routine, it is also important for students to continue learning and engaging their minds during the summer months. When it comes to summer projects, I believe they are best designed by the students themselves rather than the teachers.

Allowing students to design their own summer projects empowers them and gives them a sense of autonomy over their learning. When students get to choose what they want to learn more about and how they want to demonstrate that learning, they are more motivated to complete meaningful work. In contrast, teacher-designed projects may seem like just another assignment and not inspire creativity or curiosity in the way that student-chosen topics can. 

Students know their own interests best. By letting them select a subject that truly fascinates them, students are more likely to engage deeply with the material and gain a deeper understanding. For example, a student passionate about animals may choose to research endangered species or volunteer at a local shelter. Another interested in technology could develop a coding skill over the summer. When the work is personally meaningful, students gain intrinsic motivation to persevere with challenges.

Of course, providing guidelines and parameters is still important with student-designed projects. Teachers should outline minimum requirements for content coverage and presentation format. They can also suggest topics if a student needs inspiration. However, within those guardrails, maximum choice should be given. Students then take ownership over the direction and outcome of their work.

In conclusion, to ensure summer projects continue students' growth while retaining an element of fun, they are best designed by the students themselves under teacher guidance. Student choice leads to greater engagement, creativity and intrinsic motivation to learn - key qualities that any educational experience should aim to nurture.

essay_title: Your principal has decided that all students must participate in at least one extracurricular activity. For example, students could participate in sports, work on the yearbook, or serve on the student council. Do you agree or disagree with this decision? Use specific details and examples to convince others to support your position.
essay_text:
I respectfully disagree with making extracurricular activities mandatory for all students. While activities can offer valuable benefits, forcing participation risks damaging those very benefits and inflicting undue stress. Each individual should have the freedom to choose how to spend their time outside of academics.

Extracurriculars are most worthwhile when students find experiences that fit their unique interests and strengths. Forcing participation could crowd out opportunities more aligned with a student's passions, weakening the developmental and educational gains extracurriculars aim to provide. A one-size-fits-all approach also fails to account for differing home obligations, responsibilities, financial constraints or health/disability needs that may make mandatory participation unreasonable for some.  

Instead of mandating activities, schools would do better supporting student choice. Providing diverse options, balancing academic and extracurricular calendars, and reducing barriers to participation (e.g. transportation, costs) empowers students to explore and build agency. Schools could also recognize volunteering, hobbies and part-time jobs as valid ways for students to develop skills and spend free time.

Mandatory participation risks having the opposite effect by creating resentment and burnout. The stress of maintaining good grades while spending mandatory hours each week on an unwanted activity may damage mental health and academic performance. Extracurriculars are meant to complement academics, not compound pressure. Forcing involvement invalidates personal needs and autonomy in a way counter to fostering engagement and well-being.

In conclusion, while extracurricular activities offer benefits, mandating uniform participation denies students’ freedom and risks defeating the very purpose such activities aim to serve. Schools should instead support diverse options and reduce barriers to allow each individual to find experiences aligned with their strengths, interests and circumstances. Forcing one-size-fits-all involvement risks counterproductive consequences contrary to student development.

essay_title: You have just read the article, 'A Cowboy Who Rode the Waves.' Luke's participation in the Seagoing Cowboys program allowed him to experience adventures and visit many unique places. Using information from the article, write an argument from Luke's point of view convincing others to participate in the Seagoing Cowboys program. Be sure to include: reasons to join the program; details from the article to support Luke's claims; an introduction, a body, and a conclusion to your essay.
essay_text:
The Open Seas Beckon New Adventures

Growing up in rural Wyoming, I've always felt confined by the endless fields and predictable routine of ranch life. While I love working with cattle, I yearned for something more exciting - a chance to see what lies beyond the horizon. That's why when I heard about the Seagoing Cowboys program, I knew I had to participate. this unique opportunity offers experiences you simply can't find on dry land. 

The article describes the thrills of learning to steer a forty-foot sailboat and voyaging to far-flung locations across the Pacific. As someone who's used to wide open plains, handling a craft on the even vaster ocean was a thrill like nothing I'd ever known before. Navigating rough waters and high winds took grit and determination, but gaining such a skill pushed me far outside my comfort zone in the best way. I also appreciated visiting new cultures in places like Hawaii, Tahiti and Fiji - it opened my eyes to communities utterly different than my own small Wyoming town.

Perhaps most remarkably, the program immersed me in incredible natural environments. Snorkeling through colorful coral reefs and spotting humpback whales breach the waves are memories I'll treasure forever. I even hand-fed sea lions one morning! Experiences that exotic are things most people will never experience without a program like this. Now whenever I start to feel cooped up on the ranch, I just think of the tropical islands and majestic marine life I encountered. That helps me appreciate what I have back home even more.  

In short, if you want adventure, excitement, valuable skills and a lifetime of stories, the Seagoing Cowboys program is unbeatable. I wholeheartedly recommend signing up - it might be uncomfortable stepping outside your comfort zone at first, like it was for me. But I promise the rewards will last you a lifetime, just as they have for me. The open seas are calling - all it takes is answering their siren song.

essay_title: When people ask for advice, they sometimes talk to more than one person. Explain why seeking multiple opinions can help someone make a better choice. Use specific details and examples in your response.
essay_text:
When faced with an important decision, it's natural to want to get different perspectives before committing to a choice. Seeing an issue from multiple angles can uncover aspects that may not be obvious from a single point of view. Getting advice from more than one person has several benefits.

Firstly, different people will likely have different experiences and areas of expertise that are relevant. For example, if trying to choose between careers, talking to someone in each field can provide insider insights into what the daily work is really like. One advisor may focus on opportunities for advancement, while another highlights work-life balance. Considering a wider range of factors leads to a more well-rounded analysis. 

In addition, other viewpoints can challenge preconceptions and assumptions. We all have blind spots, and discussing an issue openly with trusted advisors makes it easier to see beyond initial biases. Multiple counselors may spot drawbacks or risks that one may overlook alone. Working through critiques of various options strengthens the eventual decision.

Perhaps most importantly, seeking a variety of perspectives increases confidence that the best choice has been made. When several respected sources independently arrive at a similar recommendation after thoughtful discussion, it provides reassurance that hidden deal-breakers have come to light. In contrast, conflicting advice signals the need for more research to gain clarity. Bringing a decision to closure with solid support in hand provides comfort that all aspects were properly weighted. 

In summary, turning to more than one trusted advisor allows a decision maker to tap into diverse expertise, ensures new angles are explored to overcome limitations of any single perspective, and builds confidence in the endorsed choice through consensus across sources. A choice arrived at through comprehensive gathering of counsel stands on firmer ground than one made in isolation or relying on a lone opinion.

essay_title: You have just read the article, 'A Cowboy Who Rode the Waves.' Luke's participation in the Seagoing Cowboys program allowed him to experience adventures and visit many unique places. Using information from the article, write an argument from Luke's point of view convincing others to participate in the Seagoing Cowboys program. Be sure to include: reasons to join the program; details from the article to support Luke's claims; an introduction, a body, and a conclusion to your essay.
essay_text:
The sights and sounds encountered while sailing are unlike anything else. Each day brought new ocean vistas, from calm crystal waters reflecting the clouds to towering cliffs pounded by crashing waves. Wildlife such as dolphins, seabirds and even whales entertained our crew as we cruised. Sunrises and sunsets over the ocean's immense expanse took my breath away. Port calls allowed exploring quaint coastal towns, from seaside Maine villages to busy California harbors. I sampled foods like lobster fresh off the boats and learned local histories differently than reading books back home. The simple pleasure of an ocean breeze cleansing away worries on the deck will forever stay with me.

These journeys have expanded my horizons far beyond Wyoming's plains. Skills honed as a rancher translated well to sailing, as lessons in teamwork, adaptability and grit proved invaluable aboard tall ships. I now understand contrasts between ranching and fishing communities, interior and coast. Citizens from all over the United States and beyond crossed paths due to Seagoing Cowboys, creating bonds over waves that will last lifetimes. Participating opened my eyes to the rich cultural diversity in this great country, right on our own shores. 

For any seeking adventure beyond ordinary life, I recommend Seagoing Cowboys without hesitation. The wonders, skills and connections gained will stay with you wherever the winds may blow. One voyage is all it takes to catch the sailing bug. The sea gets in your blood, and I aim to return for more waves soon. Cowboys and cowgirls shouldn't miss this chance to ride even bigger ranges than ours at home. The open ocean awaits - what are you waiting for? Sign up today at SeagoingCowboys.org and let the journey begin. Fair winds and following seas to you!

essay_title: In "The Challenge of Exploring Venus," the author suggests studying Venus is a worthy pursuit despite the dangers it presents. Using details from the article, write an essay evaluating how well the author supports this idea. Be sure to include: a claim that evaluates how well the author supports the idea that studying Venus is a worthy pursuit despite the dangers; an explanation of the evidence from the article that supports your claim; an introduction, a body, and a conclusion to your essay.
essay_text:
The author makes a compelling case that studying Venus is a worthwhile goal even given the perilous conditions on its surface. Several key pieces of evidence in the article strongly support this claim. 

One of the primary reasons the author gives for continuing to study Venus is the scientific knowledge we stand to gain. Venus is similar in size and composition to Earth but developed very differently, lacking liquid water and possessing an atmosphere toxic enough to "melt lead." Understanding why Venus evolved so differently could offer insight into the factors that made Earth habitable. The article notes Venus may hold clues about how atmospheric greenhouse effects influence climate. Such knowledge could help scientists better predict and mitigate climate change on our own planet.  

Another important point the author makes is that robotic spacecraft and probes have helped scientists study Venus remotely without risking human life. The Soviet Venera missions in the 1970s and 80s were able to transmit photos and chemical analyses from the Venusian surface before succumbing to the extreme heat and pressure. Continued unmanned missions could reveal even more discoveries without endangering astronauts. While conditions on Venus remain too hellish for human exploration, robotic technology allows productive research from a safe distance.

In conclusion, the author presents a compelling case that studying Venus through unmanned missions is well worth the effort despite the planet's harsh surface conditions. Learning why Venus evolved so differently than Earth and gaining insights that could aid climate science are worthwhile scientific gains. Future probes may uncover additional discoveries without jeopardizing human life. Through remote robotic exploration, Venus promises to yield valuable clues about the evolution of planetary atmospheres and climates.

essay_title:
Your principal is considering changing school policy so that students may not participate in sports or other activities unless they have at least a grade B average. Many students have a grade C average.
She would like to hear the students' views on this possible policy change. Write a letter to your principal arguing for or against requiring at least a grade B average to participate in sports or other activities. Be sure to support your arguments with specific reasons.
essay_text:
Dear Principal Johnson, 

I am writing to express my views on the proposed policy change to require students to maintain at least a B average in order to participate in sports and other extracurricular activities. While I understand the goal of wanting students to focus on their academics, I do not think implementing this policy would be the best approach. 

Requiring a B average would exclude many dedicated and hard-working students who currently have a C average from being able to participate in the activities they enjoy. For some students, extracurriculars provide an important outlet and are essential for maintaining a healthy balance with their studies. Being involved in a sport, club, or other program also teaches important life lessons like teamwork, leadership, time management and responsibility - lessons that can actually help students prioritize their academics as well. 

Participating in an activity is also a great motivator for many students. Knowing they have a practice or game keeps them focused on staying eligible. Taking that opportunity away could negatively impact their grades instead of improving them. For students struggling in particular subjects, that extra encouragement may be what helps them push through. 

Rather than an across-the-board B average requirement, I think alternative academic support programs would be a fairer approach. For example, students with a C average could still participate as long as they attend mandatory study sessions. Weekly check-ins with teachers could also help catch anyone beginning to fall behind. This balances involvement with ensuring studies come first.

In closing, while raising standards is understandable, this proposed policy changes seems too restrictive. A “C” is still considered passing after all. I hope you will consider alternative options that don’t punish dedication and teamwork by excluding good students who just need extra support sometimes. The goal should be helping all students succeed both inside and outside the classroom.

Thank you for your consideration.

Sincerely,
[Your name]

essay_title: Some schools offer distance learning as an option for students to attend classes from home by way of online or video conferencing. Do you think students would benefit from being able to attend classes from home? Take a position on this issue. Support your response with reasons and examples.
essay_text:
Students could potentially benefit from the option to attend classes from home through distance learning. While in-person classes have value, distance learning provides flexibility that many students need. 

One benefit is that distance learning allows students to learn on a schedule that works best for their individual needs and lifestyle. Some students have responsibilities like caring for siblings after school or jobs in the evenings. Distance learning gives these students the freedom to complete their studies around their other commitments. It could help reduce stress for students juggling school with other responsibilities.

Additionally, distance learning gives students more control over their learning environment. Studying from home allows students to focus without distractions they may face in a classroom setting like other students chatting. It also gives visual and auditory learners the freedom to engage with lessons in a way that suits their learning style, such as rewatching video lectures if needed. The flexible scheduling and control over one's environment that distance learning allows could help motivate students and maximize their learning.

However, distance learning is not for every student. Some learners benefit greatly from face-to-face interactions with teachers and classmates. The social aspect of in-person school is important for personal development. Additionally, not all students have a suitable home environment or resources to support distance learning. Still, for students who can learn effectively independently or need a flexible schedule, distance learning offers educational opportunities that in-person classes cannot provide. Overall, while in-person learning has clear benefits, distance learning as an option could benefit many students if implemented appropriately.

essay_title: In the article "Making Mona Lisa Smile," the author describes how a new technology called the Facial Action Coding System enables computers to identify human emotions. Using details from the article, write an essay arguing whether the use of this technology to read the emotional expressions of students in a classroom is valuable.
essay_text:
The use of Facial Action Coding System (FACS) technology to read emotions in the classroom is valuable, but there are also concerns to consider. 

FACS could be helpful for teachers by providing insight into how students are feeling during lessons. If a teacher notices many students appearing bored or confused based on their facial expressions, FACS data could alert the teacher to change their approach to better engage the class. This could help improve learning outcomes. FACS may also detect other emotions like frustration that indicate students need extra support. Identifying struggles early allows teachers to intervene promptly before issues escalate. 

However, constant monitoring of student emotions via FACS could invade student privacy and make some feel uncomfortable knowing their expressions are being analyzed. Students may feel pressure to mask their true feelings to avoid being "caught" by the system. This could have unintended social and psychological effects on students. Additionally, facial expressions do not always accurately convey emotions—there are many contextual factors at play. Relying too heavily on FACS data risks oversimplifying student experiences. 

In moderation with discretion, FACS technology has potential to benefit classroom instruction by providing teachers insight into how students are processing new information. But comprehensive surveillance of student emotions should be avoided without consent. A balanced approach is needed where FACS is one tool among many used to understand student needs, not the primary or only method. With appropriate safeguards and oversight, limited targeted use of this technology could enhance teaching and learning while still respecting student privacy.

essay_title: Write a letter to your state senator in which you argue in favor of keeping the Electoral College or changing to election by popular vote for the president of the United States. Use the information from the texts in your essay. Manage your time carefully so that you can read the passages; plan your response; write your response; and revise and edit your response. Be sure to include a claim; address counterclaims; use evidence from multiple sources; and avoid overly relying on one source. Your response should be in the form of a multiparagraph essay. Write your response in the space provided.
essay_text:
Dear Senator,

I am writing to express my view that the United States should change from the current Electoral College system to directly electing the president by popular vote. While the Electoral College was designed with the intention of giving smaller states more influence, in the modern political landscape it can undermine the principle of one person, one vote.

One argument often made in favor of keeping the Electoral College is that it encourages candidates to build broader coalitions and appeal to a wider geographic range of voters. However, research shows that in recent elections it has encouraged candidates to focus campaign efforts and resources only in so-called "swing states" where the popular vote is closest. Two-thirds of general election campaign events in the 2016 election were held only in just six states. This diminishes the influence of voters in the majority of non-competitive states. 

It could also be argued that switching to the national popular vote may mean that candidates shift their focus to only large population centers. However, under the current system larger states are still sometimes ignored as their electoral votes are considered secure for one party regardless of the popular vote outcome. A national popular vote would better ensure that all votes, whether in small towns or large cities, are counted equally in determining the overall national preference. 

Additionally, recent elections have seen candidates win the presidency despite losing the national popular vote. While one could argue this has only happened a few times, it undermines the perception and reality of every American's vote counting equally. In an increasingly polarized political climate, this could further deterioration of faith in democratic principles. Moving to a popular vote system would align outcomes with the collective national preference and preference of the most voters.

In conclusion, while the Electoral College was designed with rationale when the Constitution was ratified, issues that have emerged over time in its implementation argue that a national popular vote is a better reflection of our modern democratic values and a system in which every vote carries equal weight. I believe this change would increase participation, represent the interests of all states, and maintain legitimacy in outcomes that align with the national preference. For these reasons, I ask that you support a legislative change to a popular vote for electing the President.

Thank you for your consideration.

Sincerely,
[Your name]

essay_title:
Some of your friends perform community service. For example, some tutor elementary school children and others clean up litter. They think helping the community is very important. But other friends of yours think community service takes too much time away from what they need or want to do.
- Your principal is deciding whether to require all students to perform community service.
- Write a letter to your principal in which you take a position on whether students should be required to perform community service. Support your position with examples.
essay_text:
Dear Principal Johnson, 

I am writing to you regarding the proposal to require all students to perform community service. While helping our community is very noble, I do not think mandatory service is the best approach. 

Some of my friends who tutor children or clean up litter really enjoy giving back. They find the work rewarding and see its benefits. However, other friends feel they already have busy schedules with school, sports, jobs or family responsibilities. Requiring more hours each week may cause unnecessary stress or resentment. 

Instead of making service compulsory, I think promoting its value through clubs and activities would be more effective. Students who want to volunteer could sign up for projects that interest them during free periods or after school. This allows those with time constraints to opt out without penalty. It also encourages genuine enthusiasm for service rather than begrudging compliance.

Our school already does a great job educating us about important issues. Perhaps assemblies or classes could highlight local non-profits seeking help. Inspiring stories from volunteers might motivate more kids to get involved willingly. Leading by positive example, not mandates, is the approach most likely to foster a culture of service and caring for others. 

In closing, while community service deserves full support, I do not believe making it mandatory for all students is the right approach. Voluntarism works best when people choose to participate according to their own interests and availability. I hope you will reconsider requiring mandatory hours and keep service opportunities optional instead.

Thank you for your consideration.

Sincerely,
[Your name]

essay_title: Some schools offer distance learning as an option for students to attend classes from home by way of online or video conferencing. Do you think students would benefit from being able to attend classes from home? Take a position on this issue. Support your response with reasons and examples.
essay_text:
While distance learning provides flexibility, attending in-person classes offers significant benefits that distance cannot replicate fully. Some advantages of distance learning include allowing students to learn from home, saving commuting time, and providing flexibility in schedules. However, the classroom experience offers valuable opportunities that distance learning cannot match. 

In a physical classroom, students benefit from direct interaction with teachers and other students. This social element of traditional schooling allows students to collaborate, ask questions spontaneously, and learn important social skills. Being part of a classroom community also encourages participation and peer-to-peer learning. Face-to-face interactions are important for developing communication skills and relationship building.

Attending classes at school also helps students maintain separation between their home and school lives. Learning from home can blur these boundaries and make it harder for students to focus fully on their studies. The school environment is specifically designed for learning while many distractions exist at home like television, smartphones and chores. It may be challenging for some students to self-motivate and stay on task without the structure that a physical classroom provides. 

Traditional schooling also supports healthy routines that are beneficial to mental and physical well-being. Going to school at set times each day helps promote discipline, time management and a consistent schedule. This structure is important for developing good study habits. At school, access to teachers, counsellors and other support staff also ensure students' overall development and wellness needs are met.

In conclusion, while distance learning provides increased flexibility, attending classes at a physical school offers irreplaceable benefits to students' academic performance and overall development. The social and structured environment of in-person schooling helps promote collaboration, foster discipline and support students' well-being in a way that distance cannot entirely replicate. For most students, a combination of both traditional and online learning could best serve their educational needs.

essay_title: In the article “Driverless Cars are Coming,” the author presents both positive and negative aspects of driverless cars. Using details from the article, create an argument for or against the development of these cars. Be sure to include: your position on driverless cars; appropriate details from the article that support your position; an introduction, a body, and a conclusion to your argumentative essay.
essay_text:
The Development of Driverless Cars 

Driverless cars promise both benefits and risks for the future of transportation. While autonomous vehicles could help reduce traffic accidents and increase mobility, developing this new technology also presents serious safety and ethical concerns that must be addressed. On balance, I believe policymakers should support research into driverless cars but proceed cautiously before widespread adoption.

One of the primary benefits cited in the article is that driverless cars could reduce traffic accidents caused by human error. Without the risks of drunk, distracted or drowsy driving, autonomous vehicles may lower collision rates significantly. This safety advantage is compelling, as car accidents currently cause tens of thousands of deaths each year in many countries. By removing the human element of poor judgement from driving decisions, driverless vehicles could help curb these casualties. 

However, the article also notes serious technical and ethical issues still to be resolved. Autonomous systems may struggle with unexpected hazards like construction zones or malfunctioning traffic lights. Software or sensors could malfunction in ways that cause accidents, as this technology is still in development. More concerning are “edge cases” where a computer must choose between outcomes like hitting a pedestrian or swerving into oncoming traffic—life-or-death scenarios not easily programmed. Public fears over loss of control or hackable systems could also hamper acceptance and regulation.

While driverless cars show promise for improving transportation, the issues above indicate this technology requires further progress to become truly safe and socially beneficial on a mass scale. Rather than an outright ban or unrestricted adoption, policymakers should support continued research and pilots studies while enacting guidelines to protect users during development. With careful testing and standards that prioritize safety above all else, many of the risks identified in the article could be mitigated over time. Once autonomous vehicles can pass stringent, real-world certification without undue hazards, shifting policy to permit limited consumer use may become reasonable. Overall, a balanced approach seems wisest for responsibly guiding this influential new technology.

In conclusion, while driverless cars offer potential benefits, the challenges raised in developing autonomous vehicles warrant moderate policies that encourage research but proceed deliberately to resolve safety and ethical concerns before widespread adoption. Continued improvements and safeguards seem necessary to ensure this transformative technology ultimately provides more benefits than risks for public road users in the future.

essay_title: Your principal has decided that all students must participate in at least one extracurricular activity. For example, students could participate in sports, work on the yearbook, or serve on the student council. Do you agree or disagree with this decision? Use specific details and examples to convince others to support your position.
essay_text:
I disagree with the principal's decision that all students must participate in at least one extracurricular activity. While extracurriculars have benefits, forcing participation denies student choice and can place undue burdens on some. 

Not all students have interest or time for extracurriculars. Forcing participation risks damaging education if a student's priorities lie elsewhere, like academics, employment or caring for family. Extracurriculars are most valuable when students find activities aligned with their passions and strengths. Mandating participation denies opportunity for self-guided discovery.

Additionally, extracurricular requirements disadvantage certain groups. Students with disabilities or socioeconomic disadvantages face higher barriers. Those with responsibilities like jobs or family caregiving have less flexibility for added commitments. Standardized requirements also fail to consider cultural or religious values that may guide a student's priorities. 

Rather than mandates, the principal could encourage participation by promoting varied opportunities and their benefits. Working with student government, new clubs could form to support diverse interests. When students choose activities aligned with their goals and situations, they derive most fulfillment. Subsidies or transportation assistance could lower barriers so all who wish to participate can access extracurriculars safely. 

In conclusion, while extracurricular activities provide benefits, forcing universal participation risks damaging education and increasing disadvantage for some. Standards should consider each student's full context and priorities. Promoting diverse opportunities and lowering barriers through support rather than mandates best serves varied student needs and respect for individual choice.

essay_title: In "The Challenge of Exploring Venus," the author suggests studying Venus is a worthy pursuit despite the dangers it presents. Using details from the article, write an essay evaluating how well the author supports this idea. Be sure to include: a claim that evaluates how well the author supports the idea that studying Venus is a worthy pursuit despite the dangers; an explanation of the evidence from the article that supports your claim; an introduction, a body, and a conclusion to your essay.
essay_text:
Studying Venus Remains Valuable Despite the Risks

The author makes a compelling case that exploring Venus remains worthwhile even given the planet's hazardous environment. While Venus presents clear dangers to potential explorers and equipment, the scientific rewards of studying our neighbor planet justify facing these risks. 

Several key pieces of evidence from the article support this. First, Venus remains one of the least understood planets in our solar system due to the difficulties of probing its surface. Developing technologies that can withstand its extreme conditions would allow scientists to finally learn fundamental details about Venus' formation and evolution. This could provide deeper insights into the processes that shaped our own world.  

Furthermore, Venus mimics some aspects of Earth's ancient climate, when our atmosphere was much thicker with greenhouse gases. Understanding Venus' current climate traps could offer lessons for mitigating or adapting to climate change on Earth. The article also notes that Venus' harsh climate may have buried treasures like volcanic ash deposits holding clues to the planet's ancient geology and water content. Robotic missions braving the intense heat, pressure and acidic clouds could unlock these scientific treasures.

While exploring Venus poses clear hazards, as the article acknowledges, the potential scientific payoffs warrant prudent and carefully designed missions to push the boundaries of what our technologies allow. Facing risks is part of the endeavor of exploration. By piecing together the puzzles of our closest planet, we expand our understanding of the Earth-Venus system and climate change on a broader scale. For these reasons, the author presents a compelling case that studying Venus remains a worthy goal despite the inherent perils it presents.

essay_title: Write an explanatory essay to inform fellow citizens about the advantages of limiting car usage. Your essay must be based on ideas and information that can be found in the passage set. Manage your time carefully so that you can read the passages; plan your response; write your response; and revise and edit your response. Be sure to use evidence from multiple sources; and avoid overly relying on one source. Your response should be in the form of a multiparagraph essay. Write your essay in the space provided.
essay_text:
While personal transport provides convenience, limiting car usage has significant environmental and community benefits. Alternative modes of transportation can alleviate traffic and pollution issues while promoting healthier lifestyles.

Walking, biking, and public transit are more sustainable options that reduce emissions and road congestion. According to Sources 1 and 2, motor vehicles are a leading cause of air pollution in cities. They release nitrogen oxides, particulate matter, and other substances that contribute to poor health outcomes like respiratory illnesses. Source 3 also notes that cars are a primary factor in rising carbon emissions globally. By driving less, we lessen our collective environmental impact and move towards more eco-friendly urban planning. 

Non-motorized mobility has added perks beyond lowering emissions. Sources 1 and 2 discuss how cycling and walking are physically active modes that aid public health. Regular exercise can help prevent issues like obesity, diabetes and heart disease. When streets have less traffic, they also become safer for pedestrians and cyclists. Some cities addressed in Source 2 saw declines in road accidents after boosting alternative transit networks.

Public transportation fills an important niche as a high-capacity, lower-emissions option. As described in Source 4, well-developed subway, bus and train systems enable large numbers of commuters to travel long distances without cars. This reduces the number of vehicles on the road at peak hours. Public transit likewise eases traffic congestion and saves on infrastructure costs compared to accommodating only private vehicles. When combined with initiatives to make neighborhoods more pedestrian-friendly, limiting personal car use through expanded public options leads to efficiency gains for communities.

In conclusion, curbing excessive automobile dependence yields environmental benefits like decreased emissions and pollution, as well as public health advantages from increased physical activity. Alternative transportation modes provide viable substitutes that alleviate traffic and make cities more livable and sustainable places. Mixed-use development and multi-modal planning can support reduced car usage while still meeting transportation needs.

essay_title: Your principal has decided that all students must participate in at least one extracurricular activity. For example, students could participate in sports, work on the yearbook, or serve on the student council. Do you agree or disagree with this decision? Use specific details and examples to convince others to support your position.
essay_text:
I disagree with the principal's decision to make extracurricular activities mandatory for all students. While extracurriculars can benefit many students, forcing participation infringes on individual freedom and ignores other priorities in students' lives.

Requiring extracurriculars overlooks that students have varying interests, talents, schedules and responsibilities outside of school. Not all find sports or clubs appealing and should not be compelled to join. Some may need time for jobs, family duties or other commitments. Extracurricular activities are best left as voluntary options so students can choose where to invest their after-school hours based on personal fit and priorities. 

Forcing participation may discourage some who join only due to obligation rather than passion. They may half-heartedly participate and gain little value from the experience. Extracurriculars are most beneficial when students elect to take part based on their own motivations and interests. With no choice in the matter, mandated involvement could damage morale and enthusiasm within clubs and teams.

Not all students learn or grow in the same way, and extracurriculars may not be the best use of time for everyone. Some learn and develop skills better through other individual or group activities outside of school-sponsored options. They should retain freedom in deciding how to spend discretionary time most constructively in alignment with their needs, learning styles and life goals. 

While encouraging involvement can boost college applications and leadership development for many, not all share those goals or career interests. Universal requirements risk disenfranchising students who see other paths for self-fulfillment. A one-size-fits-all mandate neglects diversity of talents, dreams and life aspirations among the student body. Overall voluntary choice better respects individuality and personal freedom of choice.

In conclusion, while extracurricular activities offer benefits to participants when selected voluntarily, mandatory involvement for all students infringes on freedom of choice and ignores variation in interests, talents, responsibilities and priorities among individuals. Students should retain liberty to direct their discretionary time to activities most personally motivating and constructive in development based on their own unique characteristics and life aims outside of school. Universal compulsory requirements risk weakening passion and enthusiasm for participation while overlooking diversity within the student population.

essay_title: Write an explanatory essay to inform fellow citizens about the advantages of limiting car usage. Your essay must be based on ideas and information that can be found in the passage set. Manage your time carefully so that you can read the passages; plan your response; write your response; and revise and edit your response. Be sure to use evidence from multiple sources; and avoid overly relying on one source. Your response should be in the form of a multiparagraph essay. Write your essay in the space provided.
essay_text:
Limiting car usage has several important advantages that could benefit citizens and communities. According to multiple sources, reducing reliance on cars would help improve public health and the environment.

Air pollution from vehicle emissions is a major public health issue. As Passage 1 notes, cars produce emissions like nitrogen oxides, particulate matter, and volatile organic compounds that contribute to health problems such as respiratory illness and higher risks of cancer and heart disease. By driving less, communities could experience less air pollution and the associated diseases. This would save on medical costs and improve quality of life. 

Additionally, Passage 2 discusses how vehicle emissions are a leading cause of poor air quality and climate change. Curtailing car use would decrease the greenhouse gases that cars release, such as carbon dioxide, methane, and nitrous oxide. This in turn would help mitigate the impacts of issues like global warming, rising sea levels, more extreme weather events, and other consequences of climate change described in Passage 2. Protecting the environment benefits everyone.

Finally, Passage 3 explains the benefits of active transportation like walking and biking instead of driving. More physical activity from active commutes could help address public health problems like obesity, diabetes, and cardiovascular disease. Biking and walking also produce zero emissions and lessen traffic congestion. Given rising gas prices, limiting driving would also save citizens money that could be spent elsewhere in the local economy. 

In conclusion, reducing car usage through policies, infrastructure changes, and individual choices could yield numerous civic advantages. Less driving means cleaner air, a healthier population, environmental protections, and cost savings - all of which contribute to quality of life. Citizens should consider options for incorporating more low-emission transportation methods into their daily lives.

essay_title: Write a letter to your state senator in which you argue in favor of keeping the Electoral College or changing to election by popular vote for the president of the United States. Use the information from the texts in your essay. Manage your time carefully so that you can read the passages; plan your response; write your response; and revise and edit your response. Be sure to include a claim; address counterclaims; use evidence from multiple sources; and avoid overly relying on one source. Your response should be in the form of a multiparagraph essay. Write your response in the space provided.
essay_text:
Dear Senator, 

I am writing to you today to express my view that the Electoral College system should be kept for electing the President of the United States. While changing to a popular vote system seems appealing in some ways, I believe the Electoral College has benefits worth preserving.

One criticism of the Electoral College is that it can result in a president being elected despite losing the nationwide popular vote. However, the Electoral College system encourages candidates to build broader coalitions and campaign across more states. It encourages a more geographically diverse contest rather than candidates solely focusing their efforts on only the biggest population centers. This helps give a voice to smaller states in the process. As discussed in the texts, without the Electoral College system, some states may feel ignored by presidential candidates. 

It could also be argued that changing to a popular vote would increase the influence of undecided voters in just a handful of swing states. However, the current system distributes power more evenly among states. Candidates have incentives to motivate voters in a wider variety of states under the Electoral College. 

While a popular vote may seem more straightforward, it also raises concerns about election security and reliability that are avoided under the Electoral College system. Verifying votes from every single eligible voter nationwide presents challenges not faced when votes are verified and counted at the state level first. Widespread claims of election irregularities could undermine faith in results under a popular vote.

In conclusion, while a popular vote seems simpler on the surface, the Electoral College system has benefits worth maintaining such as encouraging geographically diverse campaigns, giving smaller states more influence, and avoiding election security concerns of a nationwide popular vote. For these reasons, I believe the Electoral College is still the better system for electing the American president and should be kept in place. Thank you for your consideration of my views on this important issue.

Sincerely,
[Your name]

essay_title: In the article “Driverless Cars are Coming,” the author presents both positive and negative aspects of driverless cars. Using details from the article, create an argument for or against the development of these cars. Be sure to include: your position on driverless cars; appropriate details from the article that support your position; an introduction, a body, and a conclusion to your argumentative essay.
essay_text:
The Benefits of Driverless Cars Outweigh the Risks

While the development of driverless cars presents both opportunities and challenges, their potential benefits make them worthwhile to pursue. According to the article, these autonomous vehicles could significantly reduce accidents caused by human error, the major cause of many car crashes today. By removing the human element of poor judgment from driving, we have an opportunity to make our roads far safer. 

Driverless cars also promise to improve mobility for many. The elderly and disabled, who struggle to drive themselves, would gain new independence with autonomous taxis or shuttle services. Children and others unable to legally drive could still access self-driving cars. For those who cannot or prefer not to drive, this expansion of transportation options has tremendous value.

Of course, introducing widespread driverless technology introduces adjustments and uncertainties. As the article notes, hackers represent a risk if they manage to break into autonomous driving systems. However, with responsible development and cybersecurity best practices, we can minimize these cyber risks to an acceptable level. Additionally, while some jobs like taxi and truck driving may decline, new industries and professions will emerge to support and maintain the autonomous vehicles that serve as a basis for future mobility services.

In conclusion, the coming of driverless cars presents an opportunity to make our roads dramatically safer while expanding access to transportation. With prudent development and oversight to ensure cybersecurity and address uncertainties, the benefits of autonomous vehicles clearly outweigh the risks. Overall, the introduction of driverless car technology has the potential to save many lives and improve mobility for all. We should welcome and support this promising transportation development.

essay_title: Your principal has decided that all students must participate in at least one extracurricular activity. For example, students could participate in sports, work on the yearbook, or serve on the student council. Do you agree or disagree with this decision? Use specific details and examples to convince others to support your position.
essay_text:
I agree with the principal's decision that all students should participate in at least one extracurricular activity. There are several important reasons why extracurricular activities are beneficial for students.

Participating in extracurricular activities allows students to explore their interests and talents. Activities like sports, arts, clubs and volunteering give students a chance to try new things and discover skills they did not know they had. This can help students decide what career paths may interest them in the future. Having a variety of interests and experiences will also make students well-rounded individuals and help them in further education or employment. 

Extracurricular activities also provide an opportunity for students to build important life skills. When students join clubs or play on sports teams, they learn skills like time management, leadership, communication and working as part of a group. Participating regularly requires balancing various commitments, which helps prepare students for managing responsibilities in college or career. Students may get chances to take on leadership roles, growing their confidence and abilities to motivate others.

Being involved in extracurricular activities has benefits for student's social and emotional development too. It allows them to spend time with peers who share the same interests.
