Careful, goal-oriented missions to this foreboding yet enlightening world could thus yield scientific returns far exceeding the investment of resources and risk.

essay_title: You have read the article 'Unmasking the Face on Mars.' Imagine you are a scientist at NASA discussing the Face with someone who thinks it was created by aliens. Using information in the article, write an argumentative essay to convince someone that the Face is just a natural landform.Be sure to include: claims to support your argument that the Face is a natural landform; evidence from the article to support your claims; an introduction, a body, and a conclusion to your argumentative essay.
essay_text:
The Phantom Face on Mars 

Many people see mysteries where there are none. The so-called "Face on Mars" is one such case. While its pareidolic shape understandably sparks imaginations, scientific evidence tells us the landform is simply a natural rock formation, not an artifact of aliens. 

Several facts support this conclusion. Firstly, newer photos from 1998 show the face has eroded away over time due to processes like wind erosion. If aliens carved it, why would natural environmental factors wear it down? Its features have changed and faded without purpose or design. Secondly, similar mesa landforms on Mars, devoid of faces, follow the same wind-created patterns as the "face." Scientists understand the geological mechanisms that shape rocks into sheer cliffsides and mesas under Martian conditions. The face fits these natural profiles. 

Some argue its symmetrical qualities prove its artificial nature. However, symmetrical rock formations occur throughout our own planet through geologic uplift and weathering alone. Symmetry does not require an intelligent hand. The "face's" symmetry has more plausible scientific explanations than alien sculptors. Further, subsequent high resolution images reveal its features are asymmetrical up close, contradicting claims of artificial precision. 

While the human tendency to see faces remains intriguing, extraordinary claims require extraordinary proof. No evidence substantiates carved or constructed origins for this mesa. Ultimately, understanding comes through facts, not fantasies. The Face on Mars is best understood as a chance product of ordinary geological processes on another world, not alien visitation. Natural explanations have held up under scientific scrutiny, while alien sculptors remain in the realm of unproven hypothesis. For these compelling reasons, most experts agree the Phantom Face is merely a natural rock formation.

essay_title:
Your principal is reconsidering the school's cell phone policy. She is considering two possible policies:
- Policy 1: Allow students to bring phones to school and use them during lunch periods and other free times, as long as the phones are turned off during class time.
- Policy 2: Do not allow students to have phones at school at all.
Write a letter to your principal convincing her which policy you believe is better. Support your position with specific reasons.
essay_text:
Dear Principal, 

I am writing to you regarding the school's cell phone policy and to advocate for Policy 1 as the better option. While I understand the desire to limit distractions in class, an outright ban on phones is too extreme and fails to recognize their potential benefits when used responsibly. 

Policy 1 allows students to have phones at school for communication purposes but limits their use to non-instructional times like lunch and between classes. This balanced approach acknowledges that many students rely on their phones to stay in touch with parents regarding transportation, activities, and other planning. It also facilitates connecting with peers for collaborative learning outside of classroom lessons. By restricting phones to be off during class time, Policy 1 still prevents disruptions to the learning environment while lessons are occurring. 

Moreover, newer phones can enable educational opportunities when used appropriately. Students may use approved educational apps or the internet to supplement assignments during free periods. Phones also make it easier for teachers to extend learning beyond the classroom through links shared digitally. An outright ban under Policy 2 eliminates these potential academic benefits and fails to help students learn responsible phone usage.

In summary, Policy 1 adopts a sensible, middle-ground stance that trusts students can handle phones judiciously when rules are clear. It accommodates communication needs while still prioritizing focus during class. Policy 1 is thus the better choice as it empowers responsible self-management and enables phones to potentially enhance learning when used prudently outside of instructional time. I hope you will consider implementing this policy.

Thank you for your consideration.

Sincerely,
[Your name]

essay_title: In "The Challenge of Exploring Venus," the author suggests studying Venus is a worthy pursuit despite the dangers it presents. Using details from the article, write an essay evaluating how well the author supports this idea. Be sure to include: a claim that evaluates how well the author supports the idea that studying Venus is a worthy pursuit despite the dangers; an explanation of the evidence from the article that supports your claim; an introduction, a body, and a conclusion to your essay.
essay_text:
Studying Venus Remains a Worthy Pursuit

While exploring Venus presents clear dangers due to its extreme environment, the author of "The Challenge of Exploring Venus" makes a compelling case that studying Venus is still worthwhile. The article provides strong evidence that Venus holds valuable scientific insights, despite the difficulties of exploration. 

The article notes Venus was once thought to potentially harbor life, before instruments revealed its boiling surface and crushing atmosphere. This realization that Venus had diverged so greatly from Earth heightened scientific interest in understanding atmospheric evolution. The author also emphasizes Venus is Earth's twin planet, yet ended up so different - making it crucial to determine what factors shaped their divergent paths. Comparing Earth and its closest planetary neighbor on an atmospheric level could yield insights applicable to studying climates elsewhere.  

To overcome the obstacles of Venus's conditions, the article details how future missions could utilize advances like carbon fiber thermoprotection, long-lasting batteries and power sources resilient to heat, and robotic rovers explorable for weeks rather than hours. While risks would remain, technology is progressing in ways enabling extended surface exploration. The multiple atmospheric composition measurements already made from orbit demonstrate scientific returns from circumventing Venus's barriers are attainable. 

In conclusion, despite Venus's hostile environment presenting serious dangers, the author ably shows studying Venus remains worthwhile. Venus holds answers to profound questions about habitability and climate change. Its similarities and differences compared to Earth also position it as a prime target for deepening scientific understanding. Though challenging, continued progress in technology means overcoming Venus's obstacles to unlock these valuable insights is an achievable pursuit.

essay_title: In the article "Making Mona Lisa Smile," the author describes how a new technology called the Facial Action Coding System enables computers to identify human emotions. Using details from the article, write an essay arguing whether the use of this technology to read the emotional expressions of students in a classroom is valuable.
essay_text: The use of Facial Action Coding System (FACS) technology to read student emotions in the classroom warrants further consideration. On one hand, this technology could provide teachers valuable insights into how students are processing information and feeling during lessons. Students do not always express themselves verbally, so facial expressions analyzed by FACS may help teachers understand engagement levels and catch signs of confusion or frustration earlier. This data could then be used to improve teaching methods or identify students who need additional academic or social-emotional support. However, there are also privacy and implementation challenges to address. Continually monitoring students' facial expressions may make some feel uncomfortable or cause unnecessary self-consciousness during classroom interactions. Teachers would require extensive training to properly interpret emotion readings without mistakenly attributing feelings to students. There are also technical limitations as facial expressions alone do not always convey full emotional context. Before widely deploying this technology, more research is needed into student and teacher perspectives on its pros and cons in an educational setting to determine if the benefits truly outweigh potential drawbacks related to privacy, social dynamics, and misinterpretation of data. Overall, while FACS aims to provide useful insights, care must be taken to respect student privacy and avoid over-reliance on numerical emotion readings over human judgment and interaction. With pilot programs and guidelines around appropriate usage, this technology could ultimately support learning if concerns are adequately addressed.

essay_title: In the article "Making Mona Lisa Smile," the author describes how a new technology called the Facial Action Coding System enables computers to identify human emotions. Using details from the article, write an essay arguing whether the use of this technology to read the emotional expressions of students in a classroom is valuable.
essay_text:
The use of Facial Action Coding System (FACS) technology to read student emotions in the classroom is a complex issue with reasonable perspectives on both sides. On one hand, identifying how students are feeling through their facial expressions could provide teachers valuable insights into learning challenges or other issues impacting students. By understanding when students are confused, frustrated, or disengaged, teachers may be better able to adapt their lessons, explain concepts in different ways, or check in with students individually for additional support. This technology could help foster an optimal learning environment tuned into student needs. 

However, there are also significant privacy and implementation concerns. Continually monitoring student facial expressions through computer software may come across as invasive or authoritarian to many. Students should feel comfortable freely expressing a range of natural emotions in the learning process without constant digital observation. It could undermine the student-teacher relationship and psychologically pressure students to mask their true feelings. There are also questions around how accurately computers can interpret nuanced human expressions compared to a trained educator. Technical issues or cultural factors may impact the software's ability to recognize emotions cross different groups of students.

Overall, using FACS technology in the classroom is a complex decision that requires addressing both the potential academic benefits as well as the social and ethical implications. If implemented appropriately with student consent and safeguards for privacy, it could provide valuable insights to support learning. But unchecked or imposed surveillance risks compromising student well-being and the trusting relationships necessary for quality education. More research is still needed to understand both pros and cons. The perspectives of students, parents and educators all deserve consideration in deciding whether and how such technologies should be adopted in classrooms.

essay_title: Some schools offer distance learning as an option for students to attend classes from home by way of online or video conferencing. Do you think students would benefit from being able to attend classes from home? Take a position on this issue. Support your response with reasons and examples.
essay_text:
While distance learning provides flexibility, attending classes in person provides important benefits that better serve students. Some of the advantages of distance learning include the ability to learn from home, save time and transportation costs associated with commuting, and balance school with other responsibilities like family obligations or jobs. However, important aspects of the education experience are lost without in-person interaction. 

Students learning remotely miss out on direct engagement with teachers and classmates. The classroom environment fosters connection, collaboration and discussion that is difficult to replicate online. Students can benefit immensely from peer-to-peer learning by discussing and debating ideas with others. Distance learning also makes it harder for teachers to assess students' understanding in real-time and identify individuals who may need extra support. In the classroom, teachers can more easily engage students through questions, group work and interactive lessons.

Learning from home also lacks the structure and accountability of the school day. It can be challenging for students to self-motivate and stay focused without face-to-face time with instructors and other students. Distractions of home like TV, personal devices and chores compete for students' attention. This less controlled environment may not adequately serve certain learners, like those who struggle with time management, prioritizing tasks or staying on track independently. 

While distance learning provides some flexibility, attending classes in person better supports students' academic and social development through direct engagement between teachers and peers. A blended model that combines remote and classroom learning may help address the limitations of fully online learning, while still offering flexibility, but fully distanced education should only be implemented as a last resort. Overall, students are likely to benefit more from regular in-person classes.

essay_title: Today the majority of humans own and operate cell phones on a daily basis. In essay form, explain if drivers should or should not be able to use cell phones in any capacity while operating a vehicle.
essay_text:
Using cell phones while driving should be banned. Here is why:

One of the biggest dangers of cell phone use while driving is distraction. When speaking or texting on a phone, the driver's attention is diverted from the road, increasing the chances of an accident. Studies have shown that driving while distracted is as dangerous as drunk driving. However, unlike drunk driving, cell phone use behind the wheel remains legal in most places. 

Phones provide too much of a temptation for drivers. Even hands-free use can be distracting as conversations pull attention away from priorities like following traffic laws, checking mirrors, and reacting to unexpected events on the road. Accident reports often cite cell phone use as a contributing factor even if the phone was not physically held. A total ban would eliminate this temptation and grey area.

Reaction times are critically important for safe driving but phone conversations slow response and decision making. Drivers talking on phones have been shown to miss traffic signs, not recall crowded areas they drove through, and take longer to brake. These delays, however slight, are dangerous when lives are at stake. The consequences of impaired response time could be tragic.

For public safety, cell phone use should be disallowed for drivers. Passengers can make calls or texts on behalf of the driver if needed. Or drivers can pull over to safely place or receive calls. A full ban would send a clear message that driving requires full focus on the road to avoid accidents in our busy traffic environment. Public health and safety must take priority over any perceived convenience of phone access during operation of a vehicle.

essay_title: You have read the article 'Unmasking the Face on Mars.' Imagine you are a scientist at NASA discussing the Face with someone who thinks it was created by aliens. Using information in the article, write an argumentative essay to convince someone that the Face is just a natural landform.Be sure to include: claims to support your argument that the Face is a natural landform; evidence from the article to support your claims; an introduction, a body, and a conclusion to your argumentative essay.
essay_text:
While some find the "Face on Mars" imaged by the Viking orbiter to be compelling evidence of alien visitation, a close examination of the facts supports the conclusion that it is merely a coincidental arrangement of natural geological features. When interpreting planetary images, it is important to maintain an objective, evidence-based perspective free from unfounded speculation. 

The article provides several key points supporting the idea that the Face is natural in origin. First, the scale of the features is quite small - around 1.5 kilometers wide. At this scale, odd shapes can easily result from normal erosion processes acting on the different elevations and compositions that make up the Martian surface. Wind, temperature variations, small impacts, and other natural forces slowly reshape the terrain over millions of years. 

Second, other images of the same area from different angles show that the outline of the "Face" breaks up and does not appear artificial when viewed from other perspectives. This is what we would expect for a coincidental natural landform, whereas an artificial construct should maintain its defined shape regardless of vantage point. If the Face was built by intelligent beings, we would expect it to appear more purposefully arranged and maintain more crisp, defined features.

Finally, similar oddly-shaped mesa-like hills can be found elsewhere on Mars and other planetary bodies formed through natural geological processes. Unless we find compelling evidence like artifacts, structures, or materials that defy natural scientific explanations, the most parsimonious conclusion is that the Face is a product of normal unguided planetary evolution, not visitation. Based on the available evidence, the "Face on Mars" continues to have a plausible natural origin story and does not provide proof of past alien activity on the red planet. An open and curious scientific approach remains the best way to interpret discoveries as we explore the solar system.

In conclusion, while the Face makes for an interesting visual, a careful examination of the facts supports the scientific consensus that it is a product of natural geological forces, not aliens. Unless stronger evidence emerges, speculation about its artificial nature remains unjustified. As scientists, our role is to follow evidence where it leads and avoid making definitive conclusions without empirical support. In this case, the evidence favors continuing to classify the Face as a curiosity of nature rather than an artifact of extraterrestrial intention.

essay_title: Write an explanatory essay to inform fellow citizens about the advantages of limiting car usage. Your essay must be based on ideas and information that can be found in the passage set. Manage your time carefully so that you can read the passages; plan your response; write your response; and revise and edit your response. Be sure to use evidence from multiple sources; and avoid overly relying on one source. Your response should be in the form of a multiparagraph essay. Write your essay in the space provided.
essay_text:
Limiting car usage has many benefits for modern societies. According to multiple sources, reducing reliance on personal vehicles can significantly improve public health, the environment, and urban transportation systems.

One major advantage of limiting car usage is improved air quality and public health. As passages 1 and 2 discuss, vehicle emissions are a leading cause of air pollution in most cities. By driving less and using alternative modes of transportation like biking, walking, and public transit, communities can lower emissions of harmful gases and tiny airborne particles. This results in cleaner, healthier air for all residents to breathe. With less pollution, people are less likely to suffer from respiratory illnesses and disease over time. 

In addition, limiting car use has environmental advantages. As noted in passage 3, automobile dependence negatively impacts natural ecosystems and contributes to climate change. When fewer gas-powered vehicles congest roads and highways each day, it lessens fossil fuel consumption and the volume of greenhouse gases entering the atmosphere. With reduced emissions per capita, countries can get closer to achieving emissions reduction targets and mitigating the impacts of global warming. Nature also benefits as surrounding habitats regain some quality of air, water, and livability impaired by vehicle emissions and sprawl over decades.

Finally, curbing car dependency can improve urban infrastructure and transportation flows in crowded cities. As described in passage 4, when mass transit options are more heavily relied on instead of private vehicles, it allows municipalities to reshape road and parking space for other uses. Buses, bikes, and pedestrians require less infrastructure than endless highways and parking lots. Streamlining transportation in this way leads to less traffic, commute times shorten, and space is opened for green developments or other civic projects that serve more people efficiently. 

In summary, limiting car usage produces a wide range of environmental, health, and infrastructure advantages for modern societies. By driving less and embracing alternatives like public transit, biking and walking, communities can significantly boost quality of life and sustainability over the long run. A multi-modal approach balancing various transportation options is clearly better for people and planet than unsustainable automobile dependence.

essay_title: In the article “Driverless Cars are Coming,” the author presents both positive and negative aspects of driverless cars. Using details from the article, create an argument for or against the development of these cars. Be sure to include: your position on driverless cars; appropriate details from the article that support your position; an introduction, a body, and a conclusion to your argumentative essay.
essay_text:
The Rise of Driverless Cars

The development of driverless vehicles brings both promise and peril. While autonomous transportation could deliver notable economic and safety benefits, meaningful challenges regarding technology, policy, and public acceptance remain unsolved. Upon thorough consideration of risks and rewards, a balanced approach seems most prudent. 

Disruption often breeds uncertainty, yet driverless cars may positively impact lives in numerous ways. By removing human error from the equation, collisions and traffic deaths could markedly decrease. According to the article, ninety percent of highway accidents involve human error as a direct or indirect cause. With computers navigating roads instead of people, these avoidable tragedies may become scarce. Additionally, driverless taxis could expand mobility for those unable to drive due to age, ability, or choice. By gaining independent transportation access, many could participate more freely in work, education, and civic life. 

At the same time, concerns exist. While current prototypes function well in controlled conditions, open-road challenges differ vastly. Weather, construction, unusual objects—complex real-world variables may confuse even advanced computers. Systems therefore require extensive testing under diverse circumstances before widespread deployment. Privacy also warrants attention, as information collected could reveal personal details if misused. Lawmakers must proactively address liability in inevitable incidents, as responsibility remains nebulous when neither human nor machine fully directs a vehicle. Public trust depends on technology, companies, and policymakers prioritizing safety.

Overall, driverless cars portray both opportunity and hazard. With care and oversight to safeguard individuals at each phase of adoption, autonomous vehicles need not remain a distant prospect. A phased rollout addressing technical, regulatory, and social dimensions responsibly could help realize driverless transportation's upsides while reducing downsides. But rushing headlong risks undermining benefits, or worse. A watchful eye must guide this transformation to ensure its promise outweighs its perils.

essay_title: Some schools require students to complete summer projects to assure they continue learning during their break. Should these summer projects be teacher-designed or student-designed? Take a position on this question. Support your response with reasons and specific examples.
essay_text:
Schools should allow students to design their own summer projects rather than having teachers design them. There are a few key reasons for this. 

First, letting students choose their own projects promotes autonomy and independence. When students feel ownership over their learning, they are more motivated and engaged with the work. If a teacher assigns a project, some students may see it as just more work assigned over summer break. But if students can pursue a topic they find genuinely interesting, they will be excited to spend time on it. 

Second, student-designed projects allow for more flexibility and creativity. Teachers have to consider learning standards and what all students need to review over the summer. But individual students have different strengths, weaknesses, and interests. By letting students follow their own interests, there is more opportunity for creative thinking and exploration of new ideas. Students may choose to do hands-on projects, research less commonly taught topics, or find other non-traditional ways of applying what they learned last year. 

Third, teaching oneself is an important skill that student-designed projects foster. In the future, no teacher will be there to directly assign all projects or tasks. By giving students independence to pursue self-directed learning over the summer, they practice taking initiative and responsibility for continuing their education outside of the classroom. This helps prepare them for both college and career paths where lifelong learning is so important.

In conclusion, summer projects will be much more meaningful and impactful if students have ownership over the design. Creativity, independence, and self-directed learning skills are better developed when students follow their natural curiosity to guide their projects rather than having topics assigned. Overall, student-designed summer work promotes improved motivation and a love of learning that will help students achieve ongoing academic success.

essay_title: You have just read the article, 'A Cowboy Who Rode the Waves.' Luke's participation in the Seagoing Cowboys program allowed him to experience adventures and visit many unique places. Using information from the article, write an argument from Luke's point of view convincing others to participate in the Seagoing Cowboys program. Be sure to include: reasons to join the program; details from the article to support Luke's claims; an introduction, a body, and a conclusion to your essay.
essay_text:
The Open Sea Beckons

The Seagoing Cowboys program offers remarkable opportunities that one simply cannot find anywhere else. Through this unique program, I have experienced adventures beyond my wildest dreams and gained a broader perspective that will surely last a lifetime. What started as an interest in ranching and the ocean has transformed my life in the most fulfilling of ways. I feel compelled to share the immense benefits of participation, in hopes that others may discover their own potential through similar experiences.  

Traveling the world's waters astride a tall ship has opened my eyes to diverse cultures, landscapes and ways of life. In each new port, I have witnessed traditions both familiar and foreign. Interacting with locals has fostered an appreciation for global interconnectedness. Whether learning the fishing techniques of an Alaskan tribe or observing religious ceremonies in tropical islands, I am constantly reminded of our shared humanity across boundaries. Exposure to varied peoples and places has nurtured my compassion and eagerness to understand others.

Yet perhaps the greatest gift has been pushing beyond my perceived limits. As a cowboy accustomed to wide open plains, stepping onto a heaving deck presented novel challenges. Through steadfast training and days spent battling turbulent seas, I have gained unmatched confidence in my ability to adapt. Now even the fiercest of storms provoke excitement rather than fear. Constantly facing uncertainties has cultivated resilience, as each victory, no matter how small, spurs me toward greater achievements. I have been humbled by the sheer power of the ocean while also feeling its invigorating effects on both body and spirit. 

In summary, the Seagoing Cowboys program unlocks potential that was previously unseen. It broadens perspectives and nurtures qualities like empathy, courage and flexibility that serve one well in all areas of life. For those eager to journey beyond ordinary experience, I encourage joining our crew. The open sea beckons you to make its acquaintance and make your own discoveries within. The lasting rewards are well worth any initial discomfort venturing into uncharted waters may bring. I guarantee memories to last a lifetime and lessons to guide your steps wherever they may roam.

essay_title: In the article “Driverless Cars are Coming,” the author presents both positive and negative aspects of driverless cars. Using details from the article, create an argument for or against the development of these cars. Be sure to include: your position on driverless cars; appropriate details from the article that support your position; an introduction, a body, and a conclusion to your argumentative essay.
essay_text:
While technology often progresses society in positive ways, the development of driverless cars presents serious risks that outweigh their potential benefits. According to the article, these autonomous vehicles could reduce traffic accidents and fuel consumption by making roads safer and more efficient. However, replacing human drivers with algorithms introduces new forms of vulnerability that threaten both privacy and safety. 

For one, removing the human element from driving means removing human judgement from potentially dangerous situations on the road. While programmers aim to account for as many scenarios as possible, it is unrealistic to expect software alone to navigate the complex, unpredictable nature of real-world traffic with the same competence as a person. Moreover, overreliance on technology could have unintended social consequences like reducing situational awareness and weakening critical thinking behind the wheel over time.

In addition, connecting vehicles to wireless networks and databases raises serious privacy and security issues. As the article notes, hackers could potentially gain control of or access sensitive location data from driverless cars. This level of remote access and data collection creates new targets for those who wish to do harm. Ensuring cyber protections capable of preventing any malicious infiltration or misuse of private consumer information would require not only extensive research but also constant monitoring and upgrades - an enormous ongoing task. 

Finally, the legal uncertainties surrounding accidents involving autonomous vehicles threaten to delay widespread adoption even further. Questions around assigning financial liability and fault in crashes where software, not a person, was directly in control will likely produce lengthy legal battles and complicated policy debates. Until regulations comprehensively address accountability, full deployment of driverless vehicles on public roads faces major social and legislative obstacles.

In conclusion, while the idea of driverless cars proposes benefits of increased mobility and traffic flow, the realities of replacing skilled human judgment with algorithms, connecting vehicles to networks, and transferring complete legal responsibility to corporations demands more than currently exists. For the foreseeable future, the risks of cyber attacks, software failures, and decreased personal oversight outweigh potential upsides. Progressing with greater caution around developing foolproof security, backup human control, and coordinated policy seems the most responsible path forward.
